posts.com:
>>2399005
The list of vaccines you probably need to be prudent goes down if you're staying in cities. Assuming you got your childhood vaccinations (MMR, DTaP, Polio), the most important are Hep A/B and Typhoid. You should get Tetanus booster as well unless you had a booster within the last 10 years (you probably had one at 12 years old). If you're going to Cambodia, also consider Cholera vaccination, which is a drinkable vaccine and gives some protection against food poisoning too.
If you plan on spending time in the countryside, you should get Japanese Encephalitis and strongly consider getting 3 shot Rabies PREP. (You'll still need to get any risky animal encounters treated but getting the 3 shots in advance will stop your trip from being ruined and might save your life if you don't get any further treatment.) These shots are really expensive in Western countries but they're cheap if you get them in SEA.
And rather than taking advice from randoms on the Internet, you should visit a travel medicine doctor. They'll try to sell you on a lot more vaccines than you probably need, but they'll rank their importance depending on your destinations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2399245
>How is it with cash? Is it necessary or can you function with just a card?
You can do almost everything with a card. Mid-sized and bigger restaurants will take it, use booking sites to do all your hotel reservations, convenience and grocery stores will do Apple Pay, Grab and Food Panda can use a card, etc. (Grab can be picky with your card - it will need to be one that can do security authorization PINs.) You'll need cash for street and cheap restaurants, most bars, night markets, prozzies, etc.
>Any services to specifically take/avoid? (especially getting from the airport to hotel, how do I not get scammed/overcharged?)
Fly in BKK and take the metro in the basement of the airport directly into the city. You'll probably take it to Phaya Thai, where you walk through a connecting tunnel to connect to the BTS. Make sure your hotel is near a BTS or MTS station.
Don't use taxis. They've gotten better in recent years but you'll always have less problems sticking with Grab.
Whenever someone tries to sell you something, say "my krop". The "my" part means "no" and "krop" is a respectful word that makes anything polite. (Women say "ka" - don't imitate female Thai or you'll be a joke.) Adding "krop" takes the edge off anything you say, and even a drunken Thai looking to start something will probably look elsewhere
>Are there any cooming forums? I have read bits here, but would like to read up on experiences and places more so I know what im getting into.
I forget their names. Just google.
>Can I find a reasonably priced hotel with a gym/pool or are those only the upper tier ones?
Easier to find hotels with pools than gyms, and the gyms are usually shit. If you're lucky, there will be some machines that max out low. Look for 4 star hotels.
>How is tinder/other apps in there? Do the girls speak english enough to hold a convo?
Thailand is life on easy mode. Pay for Tinder Gold, set your profile to Bangkok and just wait for the matches to roll in.

>>2399699
>I'm also looking for a place where I can reasonably get a visa that will allow me to stay for at least a year.
This is not a thing that is available to you in the Schengen area. You get 90 days visa-free as a Yank then have to buzz off out of the area for 90 days. Best you could do is 90 days anywhere in Western Europe, 90 days somewhere else (Serbia, Romania), 90 days back in the Schengen countries, 90 days out again. UK will let you in for six months, the aforementioned Albania for a year. But other than these, the poster above is right when he says Europe is full. Even long-stay visas are usually only good for 90 days at a time unless you’re working or studying.

If you're on day 3 you can be sure it will go away soon. I've been to Vietnam twice and it took exactly 4 days to stop shitting liquid each time. However, I may have been shitting liquid but I wasn't exactly shitting more frequently than usual, which was convenient I guess.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Before you go, for a few weeks, and while you're there, take pro biotics. It doesn't matter if you haven't already started, starting now could help.
Avoid spicy food for a few days.
Only eat at higher end places for a few days, hygiene is the killer. Wash your hands thoroughly before eating.
Only drink fluids from sealed containers. Do not accept ice. Do not get water in your mouth when you shower. Use water from a sealed water bottle when you brush your teeth, including rinsing the brush.
Sounds excessive, and some of it doesn't have to be permanent, but it will help you get your stomach back to normal.
In a desperate situation, like before a flight, take imodium which you should be able to get over the counter at a pharmacy. It will stop the squirts temporarily, but remember your body is doing that to flush out bacteria and inflammatory stuff in your system, you want to get it out, abusing imodium could lead to something more serious so only use it when you want to avoid shitting your pants on a bus or something.
Over time you'll get more resistant to common bacteria in a country, but you should still try to maximise hygiene where possible.

>>2398016
Itaewon is dead, don't go. The crowd crush made it so nobody goes there. Hongdae has better bars and clubs. Itaewon is mostly longues--great with friends, but boring if you wanna go and party, meet random people, and your typical nightlife experience. There's also a lot more clubs and bars in Hongdae, much more compact too. There's a main drag in Itaewon that parallels the main road, which is where >90% of the action is vs Hongdae which is multiple roads packed full of clubs, bars, norebangs, food, whatever. Just full of a ton of stuff. Itaewon is more expensive and has stricter dress codes, which is likely due to Hongdae mostly being very young college kids.

Mike's Cabin is mandatory for all foreigners to visit. They play latin music, but its very foreigner friendly, great drinks, cheap, big, and because it's so foreigner friendly all the Koreans there are going to be more receptive to you. From there you have other options depending on what music you like. Aura and Cocoon, which play electronic music--unless you go the Aura Bar which is connected but separate from Aura. NB2 and Sinkhole are hiphop clubs.

I highly recommend you club hop. Do not stay at just one place. You could literally go to, and I have, all the clubs I previously mentioned in the same night and have a fantastic time, Clubs pick up after 10 pm, peak at around ~1-2 AM, drop off at around 3-4am, and die completely by 5 am unless you go to a place like Madholic. Regardless, just wonder around at night and you'll see a lot, find a club that looks interesting and just go.

>tldr
Itaewon is overrated

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391474 (OP)
Moroccanfag here.
Morocco, and muslim countries in general, tend to give foreigners a lot of leeway because they understand the culture is different. They have millions of tourists coming every year, especially during the summer, and the ties with france and spain are particularly strong, historically, diplomatically and culturally too. The only thing they're not okay with is what they perceive to be obvious marks of disrespect. No faux pas will actually be taken personally by most locals. Morocco is the most liberal arab country there is.

In terms of public displays of affection, everything short of kissing is fine. You can hug your gf, hold her hands, etc. It's ok to talk to women, and since you're with your gf i'm guessing you're not going to be flirting anyway so it should be fine. To be perfectly honest, if you kissed, there wouldn't be a lynching either. A local would just call you out and that's it.

>what small things that aren't a big deal for us are frowned upon?
pretty much nothing. Except maybe one : there are liquor stores all over the place, and they usually sell you stuff in black bags or shit like that. Don't show alcohol on you. Also, a big hallmark of a tourist restaurant with high markups is that they sell alcohol. If a restaurant sells alcohol, i guarantee you'll see only foreigners in there.

BTW, don't have any pity towards the panhandlers, especially the pushy ones or the kids. They earn a lot of fucking money while the guys doing the real jobs don't get none and then they take that money to their parents who are basically pimping them out. Please don't perpetuate this.

There won't be any. There are lots of Moroccan women who don't wear a headscarf. This isn't Iran dude, pretty much everything you can do in the West you can do in Morocco short of french kissing your girl in the mouth.


>I mostly enjoy visiting forgotten by world villages and towns untrodden by white feet.
There's a chance pretty much everyone has seen a white person in their lives in Morocco and I suggest, especially on a first trip, that you start with the more mainstream stuff like Ouarzazate, Essaouira, Chefchaouen, etc.

If you really want to do something no white people do, go through the berber coast. So basically, start from Tangier and go west from there, so Ceuta (it is in spain though so you might need a visa, in which case skip it), Tetouan, Al Hoceima, Nador, Saidia. Don't hesitate to stop in the small towns in the vicinity (Martil, Oued Laou, Ksar Sghir) In some of these coastal towns like Al Hoceima or Ksar Sghir, the sun sets right into the sea, which is a pretty cool sight.

cont.

Imlil is very impressive and easy to access, but keep in mind what >>2393147 says about scammers in touristic areas. Dades Gorge is great too.
If you plan on camping it's very easy. Learn a little bit of the local Berber dialect and the locals will fucking love you.
Regarding your question about headscarves, I took my wife to the Souss which is the most conservative area, and we had no problems. She wore a tshirt, long pants, and a scarf around her neck.

I've been to the Maldives a few times and I wouldn't suggest doing what you're doing.
Firstly it's expensive, island nation, everything is imported and alcohol is illegal - you can still get it from hotels but it's crazy prices like $20 a beer.
Also, although Beautiful Maldives is a honeymoon destination so you will get very little to no chat to anyone while you're away. I'm sure some hotels will offer PADI certs but again they'll be 2-3 X the cost. Also don't forget if you need seaplane transfers you're looking at nearly $1k just for those

If you want the chilled out beach life id suggest heading to Thailand, Bali or or even somewhere like Mauritius. Your money will go further, you'll have more fun and you will get accommodation that's twice as good as what you're looking at in the Maldives for about 1/4 of the price. Diving is cheap, lots more tourists and all in all a better experience for a solo traveller.
If you want to do Maldives then I'd suggest one of the cheaper all inclusive islands as it'll cost you a fortune if you don't have that, you can't just go to a shop on any of these islands unless you stay on male which is a dump and looks nothing like your pic.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
You can find a lot of information/guides on Google desu but I'll try to answer your questions.
>how do i find a good place to live
Lots of websites like booking.com or hostel world can help you find a place, although some would argue you might get better deals on websites directly. I wouldn't stress too much unless you're desperately trying to save money.
>how do i learn important customs in the place i visit/how do i not act retarded.
Again, google can help you. Wikivoyage usually has some tips but there are lots of websites.
>How do i plan my stay?
Look at websites like wikivoyage, lonely planet, tripadvisor etc. Make a list of must do things and some optional stuff if you gave time. Don't over plan it, you should be able to be spontaneous, you never know what might come up. In terms of time, I typically plan 3 or 4 nights per place I'm staying - it can be more or less based on how much time I estimate I'll need.
>then there are also issues like transport
Again, you'll need to use resource websites like wikivoyage. If you're interested in Japan, the Japan general thread has resources in the OP.
Also, not to overwhelm you, but don't forget to look into visa requirements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
honestly the main issues I had while traveling alone was how to take a piss without leaving my luggage unattended or how to take a nap on a train without getting pickpocketed. All of that can be worked around fyi, I never actually got anything stolen from me while traveling. As the other anon said, do research online and avoid 3rd world countries. for hotels I use booking.com but its also good idea to cross check reviews with google maps as you might see some opinions on google that are not on booking. also, I would recommend taking some meds unironically, I now always take with myself pills for allergy, something for fever and for food poisoning. It can really suck to get sick while travelling and having to figure out what to buy in a pharmacy or go to a doctor while not speaking the local language fluently.

>>2391399
If you check the archives, recently there was a thread where the OP lost his phone. I didn't keep up with the thread but perhaps there's some useful information in that thread. Some suggestions I do have is to bring 2 phones and 2 wallets. While you're outside of your hotel, you probably just need some navigation app and a translation app which can be installed on a cheap phone that you don't mind losing. For the wallets, you can split your cash and cards between them just in case one gets stolen you'll have a backup. To avoid getting things stolen in the first place, there are traveler waist bags that slip under your pants or special traveler pants with hidden pockets.

>how to travel i have no idea wtf im doing
First thing's first, what's your budget (how much are you willing to spend total - $3000, $4000)? If you can't afford it then you can't go. Second, where are you going and for how long? You can split your budget by number of days and then check if you have enough money for accomodations, food, tourism, flight, transportation or if it will be unafforadble for you at which point you need to work more and delay your trip. You're from EU so that passport should open a lot of doors for you, some countries may still require you to apply for a visa so check before you buy a ticket if you need to or don't. Also, check restrictions on time limits for visa-free travel (can't go in visa free and stay indefinitely, many places have a 90 day limit).
>what about a place to stay?
hostels, airbnb's, cheap hotels, expensive hotels are all options. You want to focus on WHERE you want to stay. Staying "in tokyo" is not the same as staying "in akihabara in tokyo", you could be a massive distance apart from where you want to realistically spend most of your time. Look for accommodations within your budget in a zone you like, or just next to the zone you want to be in if it's not too far (or if public transport is close, available and reliable).
>what about customs?
dont need to know them for the most part, just know big ones (i.e. no alcohol in muslim countries, no drugs practically anywhere, no nudity in the streets) and just be polite. If you dress well and are polite, no one will bother you, if you fuck up a custom that people care for just apologize and ask for an explanation after telling them you didnt know. What you should know is that if strangers approach you for something, 99% chance its a scam. Strangers will help you, but usually only after YOU ask THEM for help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391466 (cont.)
>how do i plan my stay?
Research, and lots of it. You have the internet available, so use it. You can go minimalist and winging it or you can make a full day by day itinerary where you pick certain stops per day and plan a route to visit all of them. If you search online you may find sample routes for places you want to go to which you can alter at will based on your own interests. Look up lists of landmarks, museums, historical sites, hidden gems, hot spots in town and then find out which ones you want to go to and which ones you can skip on. Once you know where to go, find ways to connect them. If they're all in a circle around your accommodation, divide that circle into quadrants and explore it in a loop so you hit your interests and see the town on the way to and back. You can even find quality restaurants ahead of time per area and go to those the day you head out. It's really no different from mapping out a day in your own town. Something like:
>want to go see city hall in my small town
>oh and there's a museum a few blocks away
>there's even a really beautiful park further down from the museum
>it's going to be around lunchtime when I go, theres a restaurant with great reviews between the museum and park so i can stop there
>after the park i'll need to make my way back, but ill return in a circle instead of a straight line back to check out a church and another museum before I leave
It's that simple, people really overestimate planning for travel. It takes a few hours at most to have everything ready, from bookings to day-to-day itineraries.

Speaking of bookings, do not use sites that book for you. Always book directly with an airline/hotel. If there's a problem and you book directly, then the place that fucked you has to deal with you themselves. If a booking agency fucks up, then you don't deal with the hotel or airline, you deal with the agency, which means you're fucked because they won't give you a fix when you need it, only after.

If you're worried about losing your phone, ask for a physical map and have the hotel circle their location so you can show that to a cab driver.

> I know i would be completely fucked if i bought an airline ticket today and winged it
What makes you say that? It's not hard to 'wing it'. The only things you really need to make sure of are:
>Visa requirements
Just google Japan entry requirements for UK citizen or wherever you're from
>Money + money exchange access
I recommend opening a wise account, it's just a debit card you send money to that can pay in 99% of currencies with very low fees (like 0.5%). Avoid using your home debit card, it's probably going to charge a whole lot more than you expect. Using wise card at the ATM is a good idea too, since cash exchanges charge stupid fees.
>Somewhere to stay on your first night out of the airport
Well, you simply don't want to be caught with nowhere to stay.

That's it. You're going to Japan and Korea, both very safe countries, there's no secret shit you need to learn. There are no secret cultural customs you should learn. You're (probably) a white guy, the japs aren't expecting you to know which side of the road to walk on.

On top of this, and most importantly. Allow yourself to be spontaneous.
If you are staying in a hostel (which I highly recommend) and someone invites to do something, it's probably a good idea to go. If someone says there going to some other city and you think it looks like a good place, then you should consider joining them even if it wasn't in your plans. When you're on a holiday you can afford to do that, what else have you got to do, work?
There are two types of people that I HATE when it comes to travelling: picky eaters and over-planners, or people who are too scared to stray from their plan.

Just know where you need to be for your flights, that's important. You might have a few ideas of where you'd like to go, but be flexible, transport and accommodation might not always be in your favour. Or, someone you meet will show you a better location.

Being spontaneous on trips is fun, and it will teach you that every day presents you with millions of decisions, most people don't realise those decisions that they make.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391753
>Worried about people not speaking english
Google translate, just translate no more than 8-10 words at a time and use simplified english, it works better that way.
>I have to figure out public transport on my own
Typically easier than you imagine. I would be surprised if electronic ticket machines at train stations didn't have a button to display in English. Most developed countries have their public transport loaded on google maps, for longer bus rides that require privately owned transport, use rome2rio. A lot of cities have special 'bus card' things, I guarantee you can buy one of these at the airport with $15 pre loaded onto it.
>Aren't hostels expensive
Almost always cheaper than a hotel. I just searched for accommodation in tokyo on booking dot com and sorted by cheapest, the whole first page was all hostels. Besides, the opportunity to meet people by staying in hostels cannot be bought.

My other tip, take a backpack not wheeled luggage.

Basically Anon, you're 20 years old, you don't need the boring boomer-tier holiday where you have a private apartment your travel agent got you. What you need is a wild ride where you make last minute decisions, meet new people, leave them behind, go places you didn't even know existed, try foods you can't pronounce, walk through parts of the city where taxis don't go, have conversations with people you knew for 3 hours yet will remember forever and come back with photos that actually have interesting stories attached to them.
Would you rather show your friends back home a photo of a statue and say "this is just some old statue, I walked there and went home." or be able to say "I met these 2 american guys who were going to see this statue, so went and saw it with them. I really liked those guys, so I went with them to kyoto the next day."

did this at your age. went 3 weeks japan+korea and the backpacking to southeast asia. just got a flight to japan, then another to korea and from there to singapore. a few weeks before i booked an airbnb for the whole stay in korea and japan. just booking a hotel for a few days and then planning the rest after works too - i did it this summer in turkey. it was a bit stressful sometimes but it works. when i arrived in singapore at 6am in the morning without sleeping i had nothing booked or planned. literally had to find a hostel on booking.com while i was still at the airport but this worked out completely fine. the rest of the trip i pretty much planned on the go and everything worked out perfectly. traveling alone without planning much is one of the best experiences you ll have. in japan/korea you should probably plan a bit more tho. check what public transport is available and what kind of tickets are cheapest

what to bring aint deep: laptop, phone, cables, clothes, sunglasses, journal, a book, maybe a spare phone if you or a family member has an old one (for a sim card because you are likely to need your own sim card for bank/other accounts nowdays), laundry detergent for traveling, 1-2 thin towels, maybe some cash of the local currency, camera, dildo collection etc. etc.

also dont need to prepare anything really, just check if u need visa etc and maybe places where u wanna go. my tip is to go to hostels or do couchsurfing to meet new peope. find out what (dating) apps you can use to also meet locals. that s how you find out about places/trips you wouldnt have known before

posts.com:
>>2391717
>8k euros
good budget but depends on length of stay and luxuries you indulge in
>close to enough for 30 days in Tokyo?
I loosely planned a trip to Japan and found I'd spend around $5-6k on two weeks but $2k of that is the flight because burger. You really need to spend the time to crunch numbers because even though you have enough to go, you don't know if you have enough to go for 30 days. Some stuff will be more expensive too, so if you want to go to a ryokan or go to a hot spring town and get a hot spring hotel for a night, that will up pricing. You really need to budget before you go. As for 30 days in Tokyo, lmao you clearly didnt listen to us and try to plan shit out. You should be moving around since you're staying so long.
A good sample itinerary for you would be:
4 days Tokyo > daytrip to fuji > train to Kyoto and stay 5 days > train to Osaka and stay for 4 days > bus to the nakasendo trail and try to stay at a post town at the end of the hike > bus to Gero and stay a few days for hot spring relaxation > bus to takayama > daytrip to shirakawa-go > continue northeast or loop back to tokyo.

This is the way you should be thinking of your trip. You allocate days based on what you want to see per city/town and some time for travel within the country. The SIM card at the airport will be a must for internet on the go. Hostel vs. Hotel vs. Airbnb is subjective and depends on pricing. Some hotels are good and cheap enough to justify, especially if you like a private room and can be social without a hostel setting.

I disagree with bagpack only, i do wheeled carry on + normal sized bagpack (not the 55L shit) so that my clothes arent crumpled up messes on arrival and just keep it in my airbnb/hotel so I roam free and unencumbered.

>>2396394
I lived in Saigon for years. It's easy to get a job teaching but you have to have a teaching certificate and work permit. Be careful of shitty schools, make sure to ask around before you sign any binding contracts. The traffic is a lot worse now than it was a decade ago because there are cars everywhere and the roads aren't designed for it.
I consider it my second home and will love it until the day I die, but it takes a while to grow on you. It reveals its beauty over the course of months and years. It also has an immense amount of poverty, corruption, suffering, and like any big city it will swallow you and spit you out. The party culture has a dark side.
>>2396396
a lot of people say Hanoi is the New York and Saigon is the LA, Hanoi is cultural capital and Saigon is the business capital, and I think there's some truth to that.

Check out some of the facebook groups and ask around. Maybe save enough money to travel through VN for a month and stay in Saigon and Hanoi for a week or two before committing to a place.

The ESL market is glutted nowadays so it's a bit harder to find jobs in the big cities especially but you'll still be able to find something, especially during the summer when language centers are looking. During the school year it's common to teach during the day at a public school and nights/weekends at a language center.

I miss Vietnam.

I am subscribed to quite a lot of quality channels. Some well known travel vloggers and some touristy/theme park/coaster channels that deserve more subscribers. Here's a list of the ones i watch the most:
Obvious channels/100k+ subscribers:
>Backpacker Ben
https://youtube.com/@BackpackerBen
Brit who has done videos with Bald but is way more likeable and relatable to the average traveler
>Dale Philip
https://youtube.com/@Dale_Philip
One of the more tolerable food guys
>Kurt Caz
https://youtube.com/@KurtCaz
Puts himself in some seriously fucked up places and situations, consistently A+ content
>Super Enthused
https://youtube.com/@SuperEnthused
One of the only bearable theme park vloggers with a lot of subscribers. I mostly only watch her non-disney uploads.
Grimmlifecollective:
https://youtube.com/@grimmlifecollective
Goth freaks but interesting vids & niche movie-related sights
Hidden gem channels:
>My Expat Diary:
https://youtube.com/@MyExpatDiary
German vlogger who comes off as genuine/authentic and has honest opinions
>Kyde & Eric
https://youtube.com/@kydeanderic
US expats living in Japan. Have 700+ vlogs covering most of the country. Can sometimes be annoying but not too bad.
>Near From Home
https://youtube.com/@NearFromHome
Best Germany channel
>Jacob the Carpetbagger
https://youtube.com/@TheCarpetbagger
Best US roadside attractions channel on YouTube. Can be obnoxious but you get used to it after a few videos.
Nobodies but showing promise:
>Obscurist Tourist
https://youtube.com/@ObscuristTourist
US vlogger/roadside tourism
>Ray Out There
https://youtube.com/@RayOutThere
boring personality but decent roadside vlogs
>Roadside Explorers
https://youtube.com/@RoadsideExplorers
Their vlogs arent that well shot but their content is curated very well for kitsch culture/Americana. Great docs of defunct shit from around the US.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2393161
Brazil has about 50k murders per year. That said, most murders are related to drug/gang problems and take place in poor neighborhoods that you should not go as a foreigner. so it's not likely.
The problem is robbery. Sometimes people get shot by the robber, whether because they tried to react and failed or just because the criminal felt like killing the victim. That's what you should be afraid as a foreigner.
Still, it's unlikely. Everyone I know and that live in a big city either has been robbed at least once or has a close friend/relative that was.
I was robbed once. I'm 30 yo and weekly got drunk and waited late night in the street for my uber to arrive, though. So, statistically speaking, it's very unlikely for a foreigner that spends a few weeks here to be robbed.
But yes, it can happen and compared to european cities brazilian cities are very dangerous. Don't think that's enough to make you decide not to travel here, though.
Just don't wear jewelry, waches, don't flash cash and use your phone in a discreet manner.
Is Brazil a good option to just chill, where you can simply go as you wish without putting yourself into danger? No, there are much better places; even in poor countries.
But you will be fine if you're not stupid and you're travelling as a single man or in a small group of friends. Brazilians naturally develop some kind of street smart but you should be fine if you're not clueless and act like if you were in Norway.
Also, stay in hotels or rent Airbnbs in apartment buildings or houses in gated communities. Do not rent regular houses. Even though the risk of something happening is not that high, better not to gamble with it.

>>2393406
Nowadays in Rio and SP a cheap meal will cost you 50 reais, a good one about 100-120 up to few hundred reais. Mcdonalds would cost about 40 reais.
A 330ml heineken bottle in a market will cost you about 5, 10 in a cheap bar, 15 in a expensive bar. In expensive nightclubs 2-3x that. A black label whisky shot about 40.
An uber ride for 5km will cost you about 25-30 reais. A subway ticket is about 5 reais in SP, the same price of a bus.
Locals are very friendly towards foreigners. No one will target you for being american. You could get hustled to buy something from street vendors, specially in Rio, for a higher price. But that's pretty much it.
In southern regions I recommend Iguazu Falls (3 days is enough) for nature (much better than shitty niagara falls) and Florianopolis to chill on the beach and party. In the state of SP there is Ilhabela. In the state of Minas Gerais, there ae some nice colonial towns like Ouro Preto and Tiradentes (just to spend a full day in each). In the state of Rio de Janeiro, Angra dos Reis (if you have money to charter a boat; there are more than 1000 beaches and 360 islands) and Paraty (also a colonial town and boat related stuff).
In northeastern region there are lots of beach resorts. If you want to see the most african city in Brazil and our first capital, go to Salvador. Besides that, I only recommend Lençois Maranhenses.
In northern region Manaus (2 days at most) and some jungle resort in the Amazon. Also there is Jalapão.
In center west region, there is Pantanal, a wetland. Not much to do besides seeing animals and flora.
Cooming is good. Better if you are in good shape, specially in Rio. And greater if you're white, tall, blond, blue eyed.
Brazilian women are easy and attracted to foreigners. Hookers (from good places) provide a girlfriend experience.

>>2393841
Try feijoada, pastel, coxinha, comida de boteco (bar food), rodizio (all you can eat meat)...
The country is huge so depends of where you going. But I would say the best months in southeastern states are april-june and september-november. Not too hot or cold and not too much rain. In São Paulo it can get near 0 C, but usually 5-10C in cold winter days and 35C in hot summer days. Rio get 15C in cold days and 40+C in hot summer days. Bear in mind that 10C in Brazil is much colder than 3C in European countries. We usually do not have heating inside houses and shops so it does feel cold.
I just advise to rent a car if you want to travel to smaller cities like from SP to southern MG and Paraty. Inside cities just use uber/taxi. If you go from capital to capital just fly.
Not really sure about hotels. Like anywhere else I just look for the ratings, location and hotel class. You won't have a problem booking 4+ stars hotels. If you're looking for cheap places, take care. We have motels (love hotels) that are used for having sex and places that attract low level scum to use drugs. So just book good places. 50-100 usd gets you great places in most cities and 100-200 usd gets you 5 star hotels in the expensive cities.
About the water, it depends of the state you are. I have friends that drink tap water. I do not, even though it seems that the water where I live is good for drinking. I would advise you to buy water instead. In Rio you definetely would not want to drink from the tap.

>>2397542
Not that poster but I'm Colombian and I've been to both.
The thing that struck me the most in Medellín is how blatant social inequality is. Yes, seeing beggars digging through trash containers is a common sight everywhere in the country, but Medellín takes it to another level.
Thing is, most Colombian cities have clear divisions according to Estrato, you have no-go zones and you have rich and safe neighbourhoods, I could see it in my home city (Ibagué), I could see it in Bogotá, where you see utter post-apocalyptic shitholes like Calle 22 around Santa Fe, and very nice areas such as Chico or Cedritos up north, that make you feel like you're walking through a safe and clean European neighbourhood (I've been to Europe).
In Medellin, on the other hand, even the areas that are supposed to be "high-class" and touristy like El Poblado are still full of unsavory characters - I stopped somewhere to eat some empanadas and in 5 minutes there were like 5 different bums that passed by digging through the trash can besides me. One of them ended up cursing at me for not giving him money.
I felt unsafe as fuck in Plaza Botero, imagine my surprise when I saw such a buttload of homeless people and streetwalking hookers hanging around right there in the middle of it, mixed up with white collar workers, average joes and tourists. It was a shocking sight.
In Bogotá you feel very unsafe in some places, while very safe in others, this rule also applies to most other big Colombian cities I've been to. In Medellín you feel unsafe everywhere.
I got the feeling Medellín is still in a "transition" phase of sorts, I hear it's becoming quite prosperous and doing well economically, but I think exactly because of this accelerated development that social matters aren't really keeping up and extreme poverty and prosperity are co-existing everywhere.
The best parts of my trip to Medellín were the times when I *wasn't* in Medellín, such as Guatapé and Santa Fe de Antioquia.

At the time he first broke he was a breath of fresh air.

Just as countries like Cambodia had changed in big business corporate behemoths, so had Bourdain.

By the end he was a limp, whiny, pushy and opinionated, shell of his former self who would’ve disgusted the younger Bourdain who started this journey.

The truth is much like a country like Cambodia- he aged wrong. The direction he went in as a corporate spokesmen for CNN, hedonism and politics (yuck!) could only lead to a hollowing out of himself.

If he’d been more selective as he got older of the types of journey he’d undertake and share, and dive deeper into very selective niche type of travel he could’ve been a true legend of the travel writing/journal genre, but he sold out and will only ever be a contender in history.

It’s all about how people age…
It’s genuinely disappointing, as he could’ve been probably the only person in his old age in the early 21st century who could’ve documented living in a Shinto temple for a month, before living with Aleut eating seals, then joining isis over a mint tea. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want beaches, south East QLD. Stay on the southern end of the Gold Coast (ideally south of Burleigh Heads). You can cross the border into NSW which has some of the best rated beaches in the country at Cabarita and Pottsville.

If you want city vibes, go to Melbourne.

If you want a variety of landscapes, go to Tasmania. Most of our mainland has beautiful but samey landscapes for hours on end, whereas Tassy you can see a variety within a few hours drive.

Avoid Sydney. Maybe a day or two to see the famous Harbourside shit, but it is a soulless bugman city. The conservative state government has squeezed any life out of it over the years, there's fuck all to do there now except gamble your pay away and buy overpriced shit. Everything Sydney can offer a tourist is done 4x better by the 3 places I've mentioned.

Personally if I had to spend 2 weeks here I'd spend 8 days touring Tasmania in a van and the rest chilling in Burleigh Heads or Coolangatta on the Gold Coast.

posts.com:
I've been travelling round aus for 2 months now. Keep in mind this country is straight up fucking huge. Like the size of the USA or China. Bit like hardly any people. Just "seeing the sights" as has been said before is like multiple day bus rides or planes etc.

And to be honest the cities in terms of being a tourist probably won't have much for you (don't get me wrong it's pretty cool walking round melbkurne or taking the ferry in sydney), but in terms of actually living here, like immigrating I've never been to a country more civilized or 1st world ever. I'm literally going to move here, probably melbkurne or sydney haven't decided. These big cities here are like modern, safe, good public transport, everything works on time, it's great and so easy. Even melblurne has like this network of trams all round the city, and it's totally free.

But I'll give you some advice - the northern territory is a fucking abo infested shithole and should be avoided at all costs. Basically anything north of brisbane is shit. Hell even brisbane is kinda gay. Townsville is some cracked out Bogan shithole. Cairns is just full of British faggots trying to sell you "tours".

Honestly if you came here and just went melbourne, sydney, and left you wouldn't really have missed much. Keep in mind these "sights" are like in the fucking hellscape of the desert or the fucking rainforest it's like 38 degrees swarming with bugs and humidity. It's hell. Like who actually fucking cares about going somewhere, "ticking something off" if you're just miserable as fuck? The fucking flies in the desert are unreal, they literally fly UP your nose.

If you had kids I don't think you could raise them in a more civilized 1st world city than adelaide.

>Would you recommend visiting Adelaide?
Adelaide has fantastic food, an actual nightlife district (Hindley/Rundle St, but their sidestreets are where the real fun is, with heaps of fantastic cocktail bars, especially Peel St & Leigh St), and is very easy to commute around, along with being far cheaper than Melbourne and Sydney.
As far as beaches go, Adelaide has a lot of nice ones, though if you prefer warmer water and more of a beachside culture, then you'd want Queensland.
If you're coming to Adelaide, there's also a fair few worldclass wineries less than a half hour out of the CBD, and a great deal of great distilleries and breweries. If you're not a drinker, there's fantastic walking trails through the parklands and the Adelaide Hills. It's pretty easy to get to nature from Adelaide too.

>>2378776
This sounds about right.

You can make India as cheap or as expensive as you'd like. Personally, I think $50-60 per day is a good range for travelers who want to be reasonably comfortable and not have to constantly pinch pennies.

For about $50-60 per day, you can get:
>reasonably nice hotel room (2-3 stars) or Airbnb
>mix of street food and mid-range restaurant food
>private and public transportation (Uber+Metro)
>enough money to have a few drinks in the evening or on the weekends
>money for entrance fees and general sightseeing
>souvenirs and okay-quality handicrafts

You can obviously survive on much, much less money. If you're staying in a hostel dorm, for instance, you probably don't need more than $20-25 per day, assuming the dorm bed costs $8-10.

Fuck--you can basically live on $1-5 per day if you Couchsurf/stay in mosques/stay in gurudwaras and only eat street food. It's fucking India, most people outside of big cities are living on like $2-3 per day. Just don't expect that you can maintain a comfortable standard of living on these sorts of budgets.

However, I do think any strict budget of less than $20 per day is going to entail some significant sacrifices, especially for people who want to do adventure sports, visit a lot of monuments, etc. When you're spending closer to $50-60+ per day, you won't have the budget to stay in a 4- or 5-star hotel, but you can do pretty much everything else without having to think twice about your finances (within reason, of course).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2378901
As a quick follow-up, if you're traveling in the country, money obviously goes a lot further. I regularly travel to East-Central India and stay in homestays. In one of the villages I frequent, there are like 2-3 different homestays. The rates are like:
>$7-8 per night for an entire mud house (sounds primitive but actually p comfortable)
>$3-4 per day for food (3 meals per day)
>$8-9 for a guide / someone to drive you around wherever you want (not necessary, but helpful if you want to visit hardcore ooga-booga areas etc)
>$3-4 per day for motorbike, fuel separate (I usually take my own bike)

so for about $20-30 per day, you have accommodation, transportation, and food completely covered

also worth bearing in mind that a lot of dirt-cheap hotels simply do not accept foreign guests, especially in smaller cities in rural areas. this has much less to do with xenophobia than local law, which requires anyone hosting a foreign national to submit a report (Form C) to law enforcement within 24 hours of the guest's arrival. most hotels just don't want to bother, since you have to create an account on the e-FRRO website and it takes like 10-20 minutes on a shitty internet connection to enter all the info

ofc, it's still india so you can accomplish just about anything with the right amount of money + patience

>Would that be enough to live in Mumbai comfortably?
Yes. However, rental prices in Mumbai are significantly more expensive than elsewhere in India. You'll pay more and get less than you would in Delhi or Bangalore. However, an Rs. 60,000 housing stipend should be sufficient alone to rent a reasonably comfortable apartment.

If you're staying or working in a more central area, paying an additional $200-300 out-of-pocket should net you a spacious, modern property.

>How easy is it to travel to other parts of India from Mumbai?
Mumbai is a Tier-1 city and Alpha global city. It has an international airport with flights across the country. You can also take the train to most places. There are regular buses--across a variety of budgets--running to other cities in Maharashtra, Goa, and so forth.

>And how easy is it to make friends/date as a Westerner?
Completely depends on you. Making friends in India is reasonably easy. However, the sorts of people who are most likely to approach you in the street will be interested in you because you're "different." You can sometimes meet decent people this way, but you might not have anything in common. Furthermore, they might simply want to show you off as their "cool foreign friend."

Dating is a slightly different story. Living in India longer-term makes dating easier, especially if you're looking for something serious--many women won't want to go out with someone who's only here for a few weeks or a few months.

Other than that, well--it completely fucking depends on you. You can certainly find White fetishists in a city like Mumbai--girls who only date White men, and will sleep with any reasonably attractive foreigner. They're a very small percentage of the overall population, but if you look half-decent, they'll proactively seek you on dating apps.

I met some of these women when I was single, and they are fucking insufferable. But if you're just looking to get laid, they'll give you what you want.

>>2396301
Samefag who lives in India.

I've traveled to many Naxal-affected villages. You can't just "visit" a Naxalite camp. Outside of a scarce few areas, the Maoists do not maintain any permanent military outposts. During the monsoon, they usually entrench themselves in sympathetic villages that cannot be easily accessed by outsiders, including the Indian security forces. For the rest of the year, and especially in the winter, they camp in rugged jungles during the day and then move into hamlets for provisions and support at night.

While the Naxalites do have something akin to a "parallel government" in parts of Dandakaranya--do a Google search for "Abujmarh"--outsiders cannot simply stroll in for a tour. You will almost certainly be detained and turned around by the CRPF, District Reserve Guard, or another state security force. Even if you pay a local to help you around established checkpoints, you wouldn't get much farther inland without a genuine contact and legitimate connections.

Here's what would most probably happen: once you enter a so-called "liberated zone," you'd be stopped by sympathetic villagers or members of a local Maoist militia. You probably can't speak Hindi, so you wouldn't be able to explain why you're there. Even if you can speak Hindi, you wouldn't be allowed to travel within a Naxal-dominated area unless you'd received prior "permission" from higher-ranking Maoists. You'd be kept overnight and then told to leave the area in the morning.

Conceivably, you could just go "hiking" across Bailadila and "accidentally" end up across the Sukma border. But even if you came across the Naxalites, they wouldn't be willing to entertain some random, retarded foreigner.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396766
cont.
You'd be interrogated, held overnight, and--again--told to piss off at first light. In a worst-case scenario, they could use you as a bargaining chip (although the Naxalites have only held foreign tourists for ransom once in the last 50-60 years--and that kidnapping was staged by a former Naxalite commander who had already been kicked out of the main Maoist organization for provoking communal violence in Odisha).

If you know the right people--journalists, villagers, and so forth--they could take you to heavily-affected areas. But if any word got back to any government official that your stupid ass was actively trying to meet Maoists, you'd almost certainly be either deported or restricted from ever re-entering India.

I cannot adequately express how heavily militarized certain parts of Jharkhand, Odisha, and Chhattisgarh area. In so-called "hardcore" Naxal areas, there are police encampments every 2-3 kilometers. If you try to circumvent said encampments, you will probably be stopped by villagers. In certain parts of Abujmarh and adjacent areas, there is also a minute risk that you could step on a landmine or improvised explosive device.

It's really not a good idea.

However, you can still very easily visit peripheral areas as a tourist--and that's something I'd really recommend doing, because many parts of Chhattisgarh and Jharkhand have incredibly unique tribal cultures. Tribal people are usually very honest, very cordial people--they won't stare at you or ask for selfies, and will treat you with the utmost respect if you show the same to them. It's also a good way to gain a basic understanding of on-the-ground conditions without exposing yourself to risks you don't understand.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2395950
>>how safe is it to walk alone as a man in small towns in India?
Generally very safe, with some exceptions. Just do a bit of research on the places you're going beforehand.

In parts of North India--especially rural Bihar, Jharkhand, and Madhya Pradesh--there are still gangs of bandits, who are colloquially called "dacoits." The usual advice in such areas is to avoid any and all travel after sunset. Of course, you'd probably be fine if you were taking public transportation or simply walking around the periphery of a village.

Just be aware that finding accommodation in smaller towns can be difficult, since many budget hotels aren't willing to fill out the paperwork needed to host foreign guests.
>>What is the security situation like in Kanchipuram (small town with lots of temples)?
Never been, but I'm sure it's just fine, lol. You really don't need to worry about traveling around most parts of India if you're a man. I've been here 20+ times and have lived here for years. I had a phone pickpocketed once; I've never had any other problems.
>>how reliable are ATMs if you have a foreign card?
Hit and miss. You're usually fine with:
>State Bank of India (SBI)
>HDFC
>ICICI Bank

... those are just the three I can think of off the top of my head. I have an Indian bank account, so this isn't something I've had to worry about or think about in several years. If memory serves me right, SBI has become somewhat less reliable for foreign cardholders than it used to be. However, SBI is one of a very few banks that doesn't typically charge foreign card-holders any withdrawal fee, provided that you're smart enough to decline the dynamic currency conversion offer.
>>how nice are the trains in India? I might travel to Kanchipuram by train from Puducherry but I could also get a taxi if the trains are bad.
Trains are fine, but--as with everything here--it completely depends on the route and train.

cont.
Certain categories of trains have higher priority and better service than others. Rajdhani and Shatabdi trains, for instance, are usually better-maintained and considerably more punctual than lower-priority trains. I have no clue about services between Pondicherry and Kanchipuram. I doubt it's a very long ride, and I doubt you'd have to deal with much inconvenience.

Overall, you'll usually be at least somewhat comfortable if you book a berth in:
>1AC: highest category of travel, have to share a private, lockable "coupe" with one other passenger. Good service on most Rajdhani and Shatabdi trains, variable on others (air-conditioned)
>2AC: 2x2 berths in main cabin, 2x2 berth on the side (air-conditioned)
>3AC: 3x3 berths in main cabin, 2x2 berth on the side (air-conditioned)

Sleeper is non-AC and very inexpensive, but you'll have to deal with a bit more hassle in terms of retarded passengers, regular beggars, and obnoxious shemale beggars. Non-AC and general can be a clusterfuck, but you'll probably have tons of random people to talk to.

I'd recommend looking for whatever /n/ thread the other anon mentioned.

Just be aware that booking last-minute train tickets as a foreign tourist can be a pain in the ass, since most booking websites don't accept foreign credit cards. I think the IRCTC website only lets you make payments through the ATOM portal more than 48-72 hours in advance. However, they have a new Amex payment portal, and I've been able to use my U.S.-issued Amex card on that without any issues. You can sometimes circumvent payment restrictions on third-party websites using AmazonPay, but some booking agencies, like RedBus, recnetly closed this loophole and now block wallet payments made in foreign currencies.

(the ATOM portal may now be defunct--I didn't see the option the last time I paid for train tickets. Again, I have a local bank account, so some of the shit I'm saying may have been true a few years ago but have since changed)

>>2396772
It's a long story, homie.

The Naxalite insurgency started in a northern district of West Bengal in 1967 before spreading southward toward Kolkata and other urban areas. However, the early Naxalite movement was effectively curbed before and during the political Emergency of the 1970s. During this period, many Naxal sympathizers and cadres were arrested, imprisoned, or summarily executed.

While the initial movement was waning in Bengal, hardcore Maoist sympathizers began actively surveying other regions for the location of a potential "guerrilla base." So far as I can recall, in Maoist war strategy, a guerilla base is an isolated, inaccessible area, from which militants can amass strength and began waging a protracted war of attrition against the urban, industrial state.

Since many early Naxalite cadres were Telugu speakers, they began making inroads into isolated tribal communities in East-Central India. The Gonds, for example, are among the largest tribes in the region; their language doesn't have any widely-used written alphabet. However, since Gondi is somewhat similar to Telugu, the Telugu-speaking cadres were able to gradually learn the language and begin "fixing" certain problems relating to corruption and resource exploitation.

Throughout the 1980s and 1990s, the Naxalites began establishing a significant presence in the historical Dandakaranya region. Much of this region has been neglected by governments for hundreds of years, from the Mughals to the Raj to the early, post-Independence administrations.

Today, the Maoists find the most support among tribal people--people who might not understand or care about the Maoists' ideological values, but believe that their lifestyles and cultures are being threatened by the state.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2396777
cont.
For context, the most heavily-affected regions, in Jharkhand and Chhattisgarh, are incredibly rich in mineral resources. When the anti-Maoist Salwa Judum militia formed in 2006, tens of thousands of tribal people were displaced from villages that--oh so coincidentally--happened to be of interest to domestic and international mining corporations.

At this point, it's less about ideology, and more about tribal people trying to preserve their rights to "jal, jangal, jameen" (water, jungle, land). I've visited villages wherein the locals used to support the Maoists until they successfully petitioned the government for land titles, after which they cut contact with the guerillas.

If you're interested in the topic, check out "Hello, Bastar" by Rahul Pandita and "Nightmarch" by Alpa Shah. They're both very informative books written by people who have worked extensively in Maoist-affected areas. They're also written for lay audiences, unlike many publications on the topic.

Just be aware that most writings on the insurgency tend to be at least somewhat biased toward one side or the other; the same is true for media coverage. You'll find a lot of left-wing whacko academics who suck the Naxalites' figurative cocks, and just as many right-wing nationalists who are incapable of understanding that Maoist violence is underscored by genuine grievance.

tl;dr: early Maoist sympathizers, especially in the late 1960s and early 1970s, were actual ideologues. Today, most Maoist sympathizers are tribal people who want to protect their land rights and social/cultural autonomy. Most of them don't have any meaningful understanding of Maoist ideology, and simply see the Naxalites as a convenient buffer to state encroachment.

(it's worth mentioning that the Maoists actively hamper assistive development efforts, preventing tribal people from having easy access to effective healthcare and educational institutions--it's not a very complicated, very delicate situation)

>>2391812
Still here, still in India (although my wife and I are moving to the U.S. in the very near future).

Urban India is modernizing. Educated middle-class Indians have far better earning opportunities than their parents' generation. You'll find many younger people who live very Western-influenced lives. Nevertheless, these people represent a minority of the overall population, even in large cities.

Rural India is much different, and it's incredibly easy to find scenes similar to those depicted in the OP. I have very recently visited insurgency-affected regions of East-Central India wherein I met and spoke to tribal people who had never even heard of "America." It's not especially difficult to step away from modernity here.

I think, to a great extent, much of this "traditional charm" is directly correlated with socioeconomic inequality, poverty, and lack of educational attainment. India still has a distinctive culture, and this culture is apparent and practiced even in wealthier households. I live in a pretty middle-class neighborhood, and there's never a moment I don't doubt or realize that I'm in India (right now, for instance, there's a neighborhood mela and festival ongoing--I am being forced to listen to literally window-shaking devotional music while people scream, shriek, and dance on the road).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393667
cont.
As India's economy continues to somewhat strengthen, these visible indicators of inequality will--most probably--become less visible. But I don't think that's going to happen any time soon. India isn't going to magically transform into an unrecognizable destination overnight. The next several decades will doubtlessly bring some improvements, but I doubt India is going to become a Westernized or entirely modern country in our lifetimes.

(it's also worth noting that the current political landscape in many states is dominated by Hindu nationalist parties and politicians, almost all of whom are opposed to so-called Westernization, at least when such Westernization doesn't impact their personal earning opportunities)

In respect to clothes and whatnot: this is very, very prevalent, especially in rural areas.

I do think it's worth noting that Western dress among men is very widespread. Even villagers in the middle of bumfuck nowhere often wear t-shirts and jeans. Traditional dress isn't commonly worn except by persons working in certain professions and for special occasions (again, there are many exceptions--I haven't spent as much time in South India as I have elsewhere, but I think farmers and whatnot customarily and very regularly wear lungis. Lower-income Muslim men are another very noticeable exception, as many wear typically Islamic clothing).

(again, can't generalize. I wouldn't bat an eye at a guy wearing a lungi or dhoti in many neighborhoods. It's not uncommon at all)

The trend is different for women. Indian women in cities often wear "ethnic" clothing. Outside of cities, the overwhelming majority of women almost exclusively wear saris and other traditional garments.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A few things I learnt from my trip:

Stock up on drinks and snacks at Walgreens or Target next to the MGM, don't buy any cans, bottles or snacks at a hotel.

Fremont Street and Circus Circus are both complete bitches to get to. Don't expect to walk to them or be able to get the monorail to them.

The buffets are terrible value for money now and half of them a "brunch" buffets which mean they're split between breakfast and lunch so the range suffers. Maybe do one for the novelty but just eat at regular restaurants for the rest, you'll get better food and you can still fill yourself up and have it come out cheaper.

If you're a light sleeper, either get some white noise generator or turn the fan on the AC up. Noisy drunk people and heavy doors that slam hard are a bitch.

Older and smaller strip hotels gaming floors either have eye watering levels of cigarette smoke or pump out huge amounts air freshener to counter it. If you're intending to use your hotel to game and can't deal with smoke, don't stay at one of the cheap "classic" strip hotels.

Comp drinks servers all but run past you in my experience. You have to be proactive or at least keep a look out to get drinks.

I ended up using the monorail far more than I was expecting. It's worth getting a multi-day ticket if you're at a hotel that has a station. There are various ways of getting discounts (MyVegas lets you exchange easy to get points for vouchers and the monorail vouchers are one of the better vouchers you can earn that isn't always out of stock).

Slots are low odds and low volatility (at least on the strip). Very unlikely they'll do anything other than slowly drain away your money.

Bluffing is a much smaller part of poker than you'd think. Call with OK hands, raise with good hands. You should be folding 75% of your hands at least. If you have a strong starting hand, don't limp. At lower limit tables the guy who raises first preflop (unless he gets re-raised) wins most hands

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395044
>Lowest possible volitility:
You play $1 and the reels come in $0.85 every single spin. Most of the money paid out by the slot goes on low wins

>Highest possible volitility:
Every 1,100,000 spins, it wins $1,000,000 and never wins outside of that. Most of the money paid up by the slot goes on high win

US slots are basically all low X bet wins. They may have $10,000 jackpots but they never pay out on low stakes and even if people play the max stakes of ~$4 you're still going to go an entire holiday never having seen anyone hit then (and a 2500x max win is considered low for a slot) . Most people will see a steady stream of < 10x wins and features that almost never go above 50x.

With low volitility, people play for a long time, but almost no one comes out with a profit. With high volilitility, people who don't win get their money drained quickly but a % of people leave the slots having had a massive win.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
Dear /trv/eterans,

I have decided to create a thread for those interested in general information regarding living abroad. I think a lot of threads tend to discuss some singular aspects of living in certain countries, but I feel like regrouping these, no matter if they're country-specific or not, would be worth it, for the sake of archiving interesting information within one single (or a series of thread). This thread is aimed at prospecting beginners.

>Why should I live abroad ?
Many reasons. Cost of life can be better abroad, job opportunities more favorable to your field of work, a society you're more in tune with (safety, values). Other possibilities include doing an academic exchange or a double diploma, maybe an internship of some kind that will enhance your CV to prospective recruiters from your home country (or the one you want to go to.)

>But I don't want to live there forever !
It's fine, most people don't and leave after a few years. You don't have to marry a local, buy a house and stay there forever. Sometimes it's nice to go out there, take it out of your system, then come back all grown up and with some new tricks up your sleeve.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>What do you mean by that ? What do I gain from doing a temporary expatriation?
It really depends on how fruitful it was, but aside from whatever professional experience you've gain from it, by doing you so you have learned to leave your comfort zone, forced yourself into socializing with people who had no reason to talk to you besides speaking English and probably befriended some, negotiated for jobs and deals with people that are completely foreign to you and learned what it truly meant to be alone and be your own island, sometimes. If you came to say, Asia, with nothing more than a high school degree and nothing else but your hands, you've also learned how to network, find a job, and to pay your bills you actually had to learn how to keep that job. Of course, perhaps the conditions that made you get the job in the first place won't be there at home, which will make you stay. But at least you're actually functional now. And you'll be able to figure something out.

>Is immigration/expatriation something I should prepare ?
The more you prepare it, the better. Learning the local language (not necessarily bilingual but every bit helps), acquiring a skill, gathering information on how to get in and what visa schemes are available for you are all too important parts of a successful experience abroad.

>why the tripcode ?
Because I won't LARP. The answer you will receive from me will either be something I know to be true from personal experience. And the tripcode ensures that if I truly am bullshitting you, I can get called out for everything i've said throughout the series of threads that will be posted. It's a win-win.

And with that, the thread begins. If you're experienced, don't hesitate to share your experiences, tips and tricks you know. If you're not, don't hesitate to ask all the questions you want to ask.
P.S : human trafficking solliciters, remember that you're violating US law.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391118
>>2391118
People always say it's the best way but the way it happens makes it so that it basically never does. MNCs function in such a way that every national branch is its own company. They bill shit to each other, and either compete with, or work in fields that aren't quite the ones back home.

For example, a lot of MNCs will have folks working sales abroad to sell the products produced back home. And the people they will hire are obviously locals because they might be cheaper or just more at ease with communicating with the locals. Also, hiring an equivalent foreign worker is pound to pound as skilled as a local is considered bad practice and is starting to get heavily curbed in Asia.

Therefore, differentiation is key. Differentiation through diplomas (Prestigious ones), differentiation through specialization (PhDs in certain fields of expertise that are needed there, for example, or at least +5 year in a field but more is better).

If you're ballsy enough you can point out a certain need in a foreign branch, explain how to fill it so they can tailor a job offer for you there, too.
This being said, a lot of people manage to get to work abroad if they have +5 years exp in dev, sometimes less. Foreign internships, exchanges and double diplomas during your studies can help if you take the necessary steps professionally to make it work.

In a nutshell, anything that makes you a better person than a local works. And that also goes by evening the playing fields. Some countries have visa schemes that facilitate foreign hiring for skilled workers. Speaking the local language in a professional capacity also helps leveling the playing field and beating other foreign contenders. Again, you don't necessarily need to do all that to try your luck. But I suggest you orient yourself by tailoring yourself to be a competitive foreign worker as you go, which will only better your odds. Also, seriously, the field. Don't go to china with a pol sci degree.

I believe in the material, meat and potatoes. I am interested in the things that I know will bring me happiness. Call me a hedonist if you want, but I refuse to do things that will, further down the line, only bring me depression, contempt for other people, and spend my precious life on this earth.
If there is a more gratifying job, a better partner to be with, a better place to be in, i'll go right there and I see no reason to deprive myself of anything that could be a step up. An argument can be made about what makes it truly a step-up, sure, but it is undeniable that for some people in certain countries, you can really improve your life by going abroad. I actually believe that a temporary experience (which is what an expatriation is, by the way) is nice to have. Discovering foreign cultures in an in-depth way is a life-changing experience and it doesn't have to be a permanent one.

Also, just because you have less value in your country doesn't mean that this value is inherent to you. Maybe being an introverted engineer in a western country that has abandoned its industrial sector translates to being a polite, at ease socially engineer in Taiwan's booming industry ? Maybe being a French chef in France is hardly well paid and recognized because we've got so many of them, but it translates to being a great chef abroad with very interesting and classy recipes ?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395192
>I thought increasingly in asia you require a degree level in whatever to qualify for English teaching at least I thought that was the case in China and Japan.
That is increasingly, and indeed, nearly always the case, and not just in China and Japan. Thailand requires degrees too, has done for years now.

People without degrees but with certifications can still sometimes find work in Thailand, typically either as private tutors or at the sleaziest of private language school sweatshops, but they can’t get work permits or non-immigrant visa sponsorship. So the work (and as often as not, the teachers’ residence) is under the table and officially illegal, with all the risk that implies. It’s been a few years since the last crackdown, but Thai authorities have caught and mass deported English teachers working without proper papers several times that I can remember.

The only place I’ve ever personally known someone to work full-time as a teacher without a degree was Cambodia, but there may be other Wild West possibilities out there.

Still almost certain to run into visa/permit problems, though.

posts.com: how do you find a job abroad? im a young engineer and id like to work in asia for a few years, im a bit clueless on how to find a job postings. i just tried linked in and some googling

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395792
Linkedin, indeed. Check on the internet where do people post their job postings for a particular country. Get yourself some letters of recommendation. References are also ok but since some employers might not care since they can't really believe them, having some letters right off the bat can be a plus for these cases.
Possibly translate your CV.

If a country seriously strikes your fancy, you could try to go there for a week or two with the sole goal of networking. Meet literally anyone with the largest common denominator, aka alumnis, then dudes in your field you might meet in expat bars that are from your home country, and just ask around for pointers and tips (never directly for a job). Also, read up on this process of networking so you don't sound like a scummy hustler.


Add a lot of recruiters on linkedin from the particular country in the companies that interest you.

If you can arrange some interviews before your trip do so and make sure you specify the time period at which you will be present.

Finally, one of the bigger reason people struggle is because they either do not have enough experience , or they're not specialists in a field the local job market is interested in.

posts.name: Tolstoi

>>2395891
No one ever said it to be easy. It's hard and it requires foresight and preparation. Even the MNC route isn't granted.
But it happens. People every year manage to succeed in doing that, and fortune usually favors the bold. If all you do is sit down in the comfort of your home and job and apply for job postings abroad with a foreign address, unwilling to do your interviews physically, with little to no investment in staying by forcing into others the fact that you speak english and the unwillingness of doing nothing else, there is literally no reason why they should hire you.
Not only sponsoring a visa can be a pain in the ass to the HR, you going there and realizing you didn't like the place and leaving after a year makes it so not worth it for them to even consider you.

You should also compensate for the difficulty of the endeavor with a good enough volume. If you're looking to go to Taiwan, do them all-Taiwan, Japan, Korea, China, HK and Singapore. Even the ones you don't want -who cares ? My friend who was in a situation similar to yours, applied to around 500 offers over the course of a year and got around 5 interviews, 2 of which resulted in a "yes".

Another had literally no fucking experience whatsoever but just happened to save some money and went on a 2 month trip in Taiwan after college to celebrate. My man had a job lined up by the end of the first month. That guy was smart however, had the great idea of hiring a professional translator to rigorously translate his CV and cover letter, and the guy just played up to the HRs.

As for me, the reason why i'm here is because i've literally tailored my studies to finding a job there.Double diplomas, internships... There's a lot of things you can do to get yourself wherever you want provided you think about it soon enough.

posts.com:
Hey OP, am also half and half

I was making 200-400rmb an hour in Beijing 2015-2017 as a full-time student. However that was mainly through private lessons, working under the table at a tutoring center, etc..

Basically I'd get a part-time job, work at it for a bit, guanxi with parents, and cut out the middleman. Turn those 150/hr tutoring jobs into 300. Parents and students were fine with my 'racial ambiguity'.

The only time I felt slighted was getting hired for a high school speech course. The pay was good at 500rmb/hr pathed up to a work visa, and too good to be true. Right as classes started the coordinator dropped me from 5 classes to 1 and told me I'd be a substitute teacher. They told me I shouldn't have gotten the job on paper (Chinese last name) but was handsome enough to make it work. Some jobs aren't worth taking

I don't know how flexible the situation is with Student Visa's nowadays but basically everyone I knew who studied hard in China was working on the side. I knew this Bangladeshi guy with a London accent who taught over Wechat. 2 hours a night at 300rmb/hr teaching people barely able to string a sentence together.

At one point I also did apply for a formal workvisa / classroom monkey job, but you have to fight for every bit and piece of your contract. It's always a headache with contracts.

Already spending too much time on this OP, but tldr Parents and Students like mixed-race, schools and companies will use it to bargain against you.

Anyway that's my experiences OP, best of luck

posts.sub: Traveling to Argentina, need ticket advice
posts.com: Hey I'm going to Argentina to visit my buddy, I was wondering if anyone had some advice in regards to booking a ticket, budgeting or just planning the trip overall. This is my first time flying internationally solo, so I don't really know what to expect.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Buy the ticket directly from airlines, not third party sites.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: look into their exchange rates scam and plan how you're going to avoid it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2398990
I heard good things about priceline and fly-scanner. are those scams or legit?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2398989
1) Argentina is significantly farther than most Latin American destinations, and therefore more expensive. Your cheapest option will probably be flying to Medellin/Bogota Colombia on Spirit, and then flying Viva Air to Buenos Aires. Keep in mind these are LCCs so you'll be charged extra for luggage. Try to fit everything in just a backpack, I promise it's possible. Argentina doesn't get cold either (compared to the states), so you don't need layers. You can also buy things there.
2) The parallel exchange rate means you'll save ~50% on everything by paying cash instead of credit. To get cash (pesos) you'll need to trade cash (dollars). So bring USD cash with you. If you're staying a while you can use Western Union, too, but for 1-2 weeks just bring $1000-$1500 and you'll be set. Hotels, food, transportation, etc. Everything is cash.
3) It's a great country, but big. You can't see everything, don't waste too much time traveling around. They have good buses with lie-flat seats that you can take to move around. They also have cheap domestic airlines. There's another Argentina thread open, but let me know if you have more specific questions. Good luck!
