posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

posts.name: Kazakhstan
posts.com:
The biggest of five countries and also the country with subjectively the least number of obvious tourist attractions.
What makes up for it is the sheer size of the country, you can spend days going across by train and experience the diversity of landscapes from snow-capped mountains, empty steppe to plain old desert.

The big split is between North and South, with the less-visited North featuring the Dubai-esque capital Astana (formerly Nur-Sultan, formerly Astana) and the "Russian" provinces and the Karaganda desert, the South having multiple historical cities dotted along the border.

Most people will visit Almaty, the most successful example of a modernised Soviet city and also the only place where you can eat at western fast-food chains that aren't KFC for a change.
Near Almaty you can find a lot of mountainous nature such as the Big Almaty Lake (pic related), valleys and nature parks towards China but also a glimpse into China at the Khorgos Special Economic Zone where duty is charged by the kilo.
Almaty and Bishkek in Kyrgyzstan are 4 hours and about 10 dollars apart by car, you can easily fly into either city and reach the other on the same day.

A underrated place is the South-West: On the way from or to Uzbekistan you can make a detour for a day trip to newly-renovated Turkestan and Taraz is also worth stopping over for a couple hours.
The highway between Almaty and Shymkent is a racetrack, especially at night, so if you want to keep your nerves just use one of the frequent trains.

Western Kazakhstan is partially located in Europe and can be used as a starting point towards the Caucasus and Russia by low-cost carrier and frequent overnight trains.
On the way you will pass Baikonur, sadly only legally accessible through overpriced tours, launches can be seen from outside, sneaking in can be risky, especially in the current political climate.

posts.name: Kyrgyzstan
posts.com:
The "Switzerland of Central Asia" has the most liberal visa regime, most Westerners will be able to stay for 60 days without any visa or other bureaucratic hurdles.

Everybody will pass through Bishkek, the poorer, more "Soviet" cousin of Almaty, especially if you need a visa for any neighbouring country.
The city itself can be visited in a day, two if you're interested in bazars, Alamedin, Dordoi and Osh bazar being the ones recommended for a comprehensive experience.
The city may be boring to visit but is very comfortable to live due to low price levels and everything a second world dweller being in walking distance.

The main draw of Kyrgyzstan is the nature, be it the surprisingly good ski resort near Karakol, the never-freezing Issyk-Kul, the countless valleys featuring yurts and hot springs, the mountain passes towards the South and the changed Kyrgyz part of the Fergana valley.
If you are fine with not being spoken to in English you can get nature excursions for low, be it guided hikes, ski transfers to yurt stays with optional horse riding.
Try to get excursions with meals prepared by locals, during summer you will usually get loads of fresh vegetables and fruits to complement the meat-laden main dishes.

posts.name: Tajikistan
posts.com:
The non-Turk outlier of the region that is heavily influenced by Persian culture has become more open recently, with most westerners being able to enter visa-free for 30 days.
You still need to get a separate permit to visit the Gorno-Badakhshan Autonmous Oblast, but you should be able to get it on the way in Dushanbe.

Despite being the poorest country (salary-wise), as a tourist you end up spending more money than in neighbouring Kyrgyzstan, be it on transport, accommodation or imported goods.

Tajikistan has some dishes that you cannot find in the surrounding countries, a blessing if you have been in rural areas for a while and are getting tired of plov, samsas and noodles.
Many expats say that Dushanbe feels a bit like Pyongyang, with police checking beards and headwear to prevent extremism from taking root and the limited number of places to go after work where you will end up meeting the same people anyway.

If you're in Tashkent for more than two days and getting bored you can do an overnight trip to Khujand across the border to see what the city would have looked like before the reconstructions.

Because of the border conflict and other border closures you will not be able to enter Kyrgyzstan without taking a detour via Uzbekistan, easy to do from Khujand or Dushanbe, more annoying when you're deep in the GBAO.

posts.name: Turkmenistan
posts.com:
There are two way to see Turkmenistan, the expensive and comprehensive way using a North Korea style tour with a guide and driver or by rushing through the country on a transit visa between Iran and Uzbekistan.
If on a tour everything will be taken care of, just pay the amount requested and enjoy the ride.
If you successfully managed to get a transit visa then you will spend your time and cash moving between towns in trains and shared taxis with locals, haggling with hotels for low rates, bribing officials with dollars and cigarettes (which seem to have become more and more valuable in the last year, an open pack can save you queues and inspections without much suspicion.

The most popular transit visa route is between Urgench/Khiva and Mashad, within three days you can see unique nature (pic related), a historical city and the shiny marble capital.

posts.name: Uzbekistan
posts.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>That being said, what’s the best time of the year to visit them?
You can visit all year around, but each region has its "best" season.
The desert parts of Kazakhstan, Uzbekistan and the whole of Turkmenistan are best visited in spring and autumn because it can get hot in summer, easily more than 40°C for days, although dry heat, so more bearable than similar humid destinations.
The mountain parts of Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan and Tajikistan have their main season in summer when you can hike everywhere and all the summer facilities are open. In winter there are fewer places where you can go skiing and winter hiking, but in early spring and late autumn you'll find many places closed.
TL;DR: summer/winter for mountains, spring/autumn for the rest

>My russian is very very basic, will I survive?
Little Russian is already better than no Russian.
Learn some useful common phrases (e.g. Pimsleur Russian) and download an offline translator. Make sure that you have a Russian keyboard enabled in case somebody wants to translate to English.
I personally make sure to write down any amounts negotiated (especially taxi fares) on paper or on my phone and show them to prevent and misunderstandings or "misunderstandings" (i.e. scams).

>Lastly, what’s that flag chart?
It's the flags of the five countries crossed with each other!
You can see the original flags on the diagonal from top left to bottom right.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>What would be the best order or “loop” to visit the stans?
If you have visa-free access to Uzbekistan I'd pass through there multiple times because you can get to all the other countries from there.
The KG-TJ border is closed and will likely remain closed for the time being, so Tajikistan is pretty much only accessible from Uzbekistan.
Having said that it's all a matter of preference and (time) budget.
If Turkmenistan opens (to how it used to be in 2019) I would enter from Iran on a transit visa via the Mashad-Ashgabat-Khiva route because that way you won't have to worry about carrying large amounts of cash afterwards.
From there I'd do the "Big Three" Khiva->Bukhara->Samarkand before crossing the border to Panjakent (TJ), going down to Dushanbe, the base for planning any activities in the GBAO.
The return from Dushanbe would be via Khujand to Tashkent, if you don't want to do the Anzob twice, you can also go via Termez, possible even by train.
From Tashkent you can either go North to see more desert/steppe in Kazakhstan or East to the Fergana valley, ending up in Osh (KG).
From there you can do the 10-hour ride to Bishkek, stopping over in Toktogul for a night if you want.
In Northern Kyrgyzstan, you will very likely spend some time in Issyk-Kul, both on the lake and the surrounding mountains, stopping over in Karakol before heading towards Almaty, easily reached via Bishkek, the more adventurous and scenic path via the Karakara valley.
From Almaty you can go West to Taraz/Shymkent/Turkestan for the Silk Road sights or North to Karaganda and Astana (not much to see but surprisingly cool during summer due it being very windy).

Obviously this is a very packed itinerary for a two-months, so you want to drop destinations and flesh out your stay at others.
You can do 4 out of 5 countries in less than 24 hours (by bus and taxi between Khujand TJ and Bishkek KG), but that's neither relaxing nor recommended.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2369632
>Where would you spend most of your time?
It really depends on what you like:
Like mountains? Then you'll have the best time in Kyrgyzstan where you can spend months in the mountains if you desire.
Like history that isn't just rock carvings and shards? You'll be best served with Uzbekistan, both the "Big Three" and smaller destinations like the countless fortresses in the desert.

All countries but Turkmenistan give you ample time to visit and visa runs can be had for cheap.

It is really easy to go country collecting (my passport has pages and pages filled with entry and exit stamps due to extended weekend trips), but in the end you do not want to rush from one place to the next because of a tight itinerary.
Yes, you can visit Khiva/Bukhara in one day, but strolling through town in the late evening or early morning with nobody else in sight is something you can only do if you spend a night or two there.
The same can be said about chilling on the shores of Issyk-Kul or spending a lazy day in a yurt camp reading a book while listening to nature.

Anyway, let me know if you want to know more about a place.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Food wise, how’s the food?
There's a reason why the region isn't a gourmet travel destination: The local dishes aren't much to write home about.
You'll have a lot of meat and grease and many dishes will start to feel similar after being here for some time.
The good thing is that the Soviet time brought foreign dishes that are now a staples of the local diet everywhere.
One of them are salads influenced by ethnic Koreans, available in all bazaars, most restaurants, delicatessen and supermarkets.
On a regular day, at least one of my meals contains whatever kind of salad I feel like that day. On bazaars they're usually home-made, sold by middle-aged women, most of them will let you try before buying, use that opportunity to sample, same applies for confectionery sold there.
I personally avoid "Pizza&Sushi" places, most of them don't do either right. Bigger cities have both proper pizzerias and sushi bars if you want to mix things up a little.

People are very proud of their bread (pic related), try to spot the differences between regions.
Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan have surprisingly good dairy products, just be aware that they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West.
Try whatever produce is in season, local fruits and vegetables are usually very tasty and fresh due to short supply chains. Again, they seem to spoil more quickly than in the West, probably because the local agriculture is less developed and therefore uses fewer modern preservatives.

If you're taking the train, take some vegetables, fruits and bread to share because the locals love to feed foreigners and see their reactions to local food and it's nice to be able to share as well.
Trains always have hot water, so instant noodles and mashed potatoes will be a safe backup.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>What I can’t absolutely miss?
Try the "signature dishes" of the region like plov, lagman, beshparmak, manty, samsa.
Eat the ones you like again, preferably at small places, the shorter the menu, the better the dishes.

In Kyrgyzstan, especially in Issyk-Kul you have to try Ashlan-Fu (pic related), a Chinese-style cold noodle soup with vinegar (works very well for hangovers).
In Tajikistan you have to try Kurutob, a salad made from bread that for some reason you can't find in the neighbouring countries.
Don't forget about local minorities: Uyghurs and Dungans have some nice dishes, as have the ethnic Koreans that operate the Korean restaurants found in every bigger city.

If it's your first trip to the former USSR then you should definitely try what the other republics have to offer, be it Moldovan/Georgian/Azeri wine, Russian and Georgian cuisine or just plain old Ukrainian sweets.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370523
>Also, is there a sim card that works in all of them?
It's cheaper and less hassle to buy a SIM card in each country than to see what roaming offers are available.
Uzbekistan and Kazakhstan can be annoying by requiring a hardware registration if you want to use a local SIM card for more than a month.
You can avoid that by roaming using a Kyrgyz SIM card, but that's too much of a hassle unless you're living in Kyrgyzstan, especially since you'll need to figure out the offers and how to top up from abroad if needed.
Roaming from abroad is usually expensive, the least expensive place for Europeans being Kazakhstan, in the rest of the region a local SIM card reigns supreme.
If you're just passing through Turkmenistan then you shouldn't waste your time hunting for a SIM card, if you're on a tour then your guide will be able to help you.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2370901
You're going to be spending some money - a budget tour of 4 days and 3 nights from a Western agency runs about 1000 dollars, for an additional 400 dollars you'll get 8 nights and 9 days in the country.
Obviously some local tour operator might be able to shave off some dollars from the quoted prices above, but most of the costs are set by the Turkmen government, so no getting around that.
This is the major reason why transit visa runs through the country are popular, you save money and have more (limited) freedom to choose your way through the country.

Any well-stocked tour agency can book you a tour to Turkmenistan, they all need to cooperate with some companies within the country that can issue the relevant invitation letters.
Have a look on the internet what interests you and get quotes from different companies, no need to pay more for the same service.
Caravanistan might start up their middleman services once the country opens and they get confirmations of things running again.

Yes, the road between Dushanbe and Khujand is the major road of Tajikistan, so they go through great pains to keep it open the whole year.
On the way you'll pass through the infamous Anzob tunnel, nicknamed "the tunnel of death" because it was operating for ten year while unfinished, but since about 2016 this is not the case any more, now it's just another long tunnel with the usual traffic dangers present in the region.

If you want to be absolutely sure to keep to your schedule you can plan to go via Termez/Samarkand/Oybek in Uzbekistan, their roads and rails are open all year round without major problems.

>>2377654
The people in the region are conservative and there's a big gap between rural and city people.
In the countryside, "dating" will consist of convincing the village elders that you're a suitable groom, a very difficult task unless you have spent significant time there and have immersed in the local language and culture.
In cities you'll face the typical dating pattern found in more conservative countries: The man leads the date and pays for everything and the woman tries to look her best.
Many young locals do know some English but are hesitant to speak, with many of them becoming quite fluent speakers once they're drunk.
Even women with a liberal worldview are sexually conservative and like to show off their housewife skills by wanting to feed you with food they cook, showing off their bargaining skills or even offering to fix the shirt you tore during your date.
You will also quickly get to know her brothers/cousins/friends who will invite you to their activities consisting of drinking, smoking and all kinds of sports and physical activities to judge you for themselves.
Speaking Russian and/or the local language will definitely help your chances in all stages of the process.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2392578
Your best bet would be to spend your two months studying in Bishkek.
There are a couple reasons why:
- welcoming visa-free regime, 60 days for citizens of many countries, easy visa runs if you want to stay longer
- Russian is the lingua franca, the locals speak it well and without hesitation
- there are multiple language schools catering to foreign students like you, both short-term and long-term, offering group and private lessons
- there are many teachers and tutors available to hire

As for costs, you can easily keep your expenses at 1000 dollars or less if you compromise a bit by either staying a bit outside the city centre, not eating out every meal or pregaming before going out in the evening.
Even if you don't compromise at all, you will not spend much more in Bishkek.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Will be in Astana in 2 weeks. Any advice? What should I see outside of the obvious?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393052
Since you'll be there in the middle of winter prepare to spend most of your time indoors, as Astana weather can be unforgiving with double-digit negative temperatures and strong gusts of wind.
Definitely plan some time for museums, the National museum can take you half a day, the Military museum is interesting & free and who knows how long the Nazarbayev museum will stay open.
Definitely take a look at all the weird buildings that were placed in the city within the last 5 years, in summer you can walk around all day, in winter you will want to do that by taxi as the bus system is not very suitable for tourists and distances are surprisingly large.
As for hanging out, pick any of the malls for people watching, the Khan Shatyr has an indoor amusement park and paid beach.
The "old part of town" North of the river feels more like a Kazakh city, the Artem bazar is where you can get most of your shopping done, including the tasty salads traditionally sold at bazars all over Central Asia.

As for food, the various food courts can be surprisingly good, if you're tired of Kazakh food try Daredzahni for Georgian food, there's a Ukrainian restaurant nearby as well.

posts.com:

The area around Prospekt Abai has a variety of good restaurants with reasonable prices, some local, some Asian.

>>2393941
That Pegasus overnight flight arriving at 05:00 in the morning isn't bad, just try to get sleepy before boarding and the 5 hours will just fly by.
The plane is fairly new and any delay will only make you arrive closer to daytime.

Remember to not pay more than 700~800 som for the taxi ride to the city, always negotiate before getting into the taxi, if you can get Yandex Taxi installed on your phone before arriving you'll have an even easier time.
Worst case you can take the shuttle bus into town, costs around 200 som and runs every 20 minutes, just take a left after customs.

You can get both SIM cards and cash in the airport, there are SIM card vendors accepting KGS/USD/EUR between passport control and baggage claim as well as outside, plus a load of ATMs without ripoff rates just to the right after customs.

Have fun and try not to get too smoked by the winter air!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393984
I'd definitely try to check in early, with or without paying for an additional night.
Pretty much all places have a night guard, so you will not stand in front of locked doors in the morning.

>How cash/cashless is Kyrgystan?
Very cash-based. There are more and more places where you can pay by card, but it's usually quicker to just pay cash, unlike Kazakhstan where QR payments are getting the norm.
I usually pay big expenses by card and anything else cash, carrying about KGS 5000 (about USD 60) with me in my wallet, another 5000 back at home.
There are two banks, Halyk and Optima that will allow you ATM withdrawals without additional commission.
>I guess I'll buy a SIM card at the airport.
Good idea, you can set up everything while waiting for your luggage to come out plus the airport vendors speak some English.
Currently O! has the best offers, but check the Prepaid SIM card wiki for details.
>In Turkey, it was a pain in the ass to get a SIM card anywhere else.
In Kyrgyzstan they literally give them away for free at border crossings and you can buy them anywhere in the city.
> Am I right to assume that Ala Too Square is the very heart of the city?
Yeah, but anywhere on Prospekt Chuy can be considered central.
Anything in the square between Zhibek Zholu in the North, Alamedin River in the East, the railroad in the South and Osh bazar to the West is easily reached on foot or by countless buses/marshrutkas.
There's a coal power plant to the East, keep that in mind in terms of air pollution, the South has cleaner air, but if you're sensitive you should avoid Bishkek in winter anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393984
>I found a well reviewed hostel near Osh Bazaar for like $100 per week which seemed like a good deal.
Osh bazar is considered to be the sketchiest part of Bishkek but personally I have been there at all times of the day and night and did not have any troubles or felt unsafe.
As usual, don't give pickpockets a chance and keep your valuables at home, but being from Brazil you should already know that, no offence.
The biggest actual danger is traffic and uneven pavements, make sure you watch where you're going.

>I plan on finding a Russian language course
What schools are you considering?
I've heard good things from both the London School and LinguaYurt with their programmes for foreigners, both group classes and individual lessons.
There are some cheaper schools as well targeted at locals, usually offering Russian, Turkish and English, but from what I've heard you'll be in bigger classes studying together with rural Kyrgyz on how to speak enough Russian to be a migrant labourer in Russia.

>>2324511
Neuquen is pretty much a big city now, isn't really that isolated, and has great landscapes.

Rio Negro is a bit more snowy, so naturally there's fewer urban areas, but still quite populated.

Chubut and Santa Cruz are pretty much full of industries and huge distances between every landmark. Would recommend it if you like isolation, snow and driving in it.

Otherwise, I would recommend Buenos Aires. You have the big city but there's also a lot of countryside to make your house there. About 100km you can choose exactly the amount of tranquility you're looking for depending on how far from tourist areas you want to go. Also, it's a lot cheaper to live there. Southern provinces are quite expensive. Pretty much the same as living in Europe.

Argie here, I'm seeing a handful of misconceptions about this place and the surrounding countries, so I'll clarify a couple things. Feel free to ask about anything else you have doubts about.

For one, this is not a "globohomo-free" country. Quite the opposite, in fact. Save for Uruguay, this is the most pozzed country in latin america. The government is more preoccuppied with preventing "hateful discourse" and forcing a butchered "inclusive" version of the spanish language than taking care of the one half of our population who's living below the poverty line. Not to mention most sides of the political spectrum haven't necessarily adopted but have at least accepted and allowed this shit to happen.
A second thing to note, I have no idea why you'd want to live in a country that has been edging at the brink of economic collapse for decades. Unless you feel like Lord Miles wasn't enough of a retard, I see no reason to leave your home to come live in a place like this. Also, you better like taxes, because you're gonna see a lot of them.
As for the surrounding countries, Uruguay has a great quality of life and everything outside Montevideo is fucking empty. Paraguay and Bolivia are alright, they're somehow less corrupt and more stable than we are. Chile is good, they recently elected a leftie, so people are panicking about them going the way of Venezuela and yours truly, but if you ask me, he seems like a very down-to-earth guy when compared to the usual, blind, retarded ideologues every other country gets when they elect a left-wing politician.

Ask away if you wanna know anything about the people, climate, living standards, etc. of any particular province/region.

>>2328122
Yup, government sponsored, too.

Back in the day when the country got its independence, our caudillos (pretty much spanish for "warlord") raided the south and genocided the shit out of every native tribes they could find. Somehow, this one survived and ended up becoming a what's essentially a cold war-style left-wing guerrilla terrorist group.

Once every few weeks, you'll hear of them terrorizing the people living in and around Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, and rarely Santa Cruz and southern Mendoza. They're always fighting with locals and "reclaiming" land belonging to the mapuche nation (look up "wallmapu" to see the extent of their larp).
The government, being your typical, run-of-the-mill leftie activist group, loves turning a blind eye to it. The last bit of news I remember hearing about is them intervening to take land away from the army to give it to one of these groups and the ensuing shitstorm that followed. Last year they spent like a whole month raiding the town of El Bolsón, to the point the locals got tired of nobody doing shit and took it in their own hands to literally ride on horses and hunt them down cowboy style. It was pretty surreal.

That said, it's not unlivable. Many popular tourist destinations are smack-dab in the middle of mapuche territory. Their numbers are far smaller here than in Chile, so the real problem lies on the other side of the Andes, it's just that here they have free reign to fuck with people.
If you see pic related, stay wary.

If you're limiting yourself to the main cities, your best bet will always be sports, food/drinks, clubbing, and some basic sightseeing like parks and old colonial buildings. People in some cities are the kind that enjoys national culture at home, and listens to american music in the streets. Other culture things will be much more noticeable if you get away from the cities, and pretty much every other aspect can be enjoyed from afar, be it music, cinema/television, or literature.
You might have fun hearing (and sometimes deciphering) the local accents, though. Córdoba is home to the most notorious accent in the whole country, and people will make fun of mendocinos for "sounding like chileans" (warning: I WILL beat the shit out of you if I catch you saying that).

As for food, you might not need much of a guide. You'll probably notice people eating and talking about our food all the time, and we love shoving that shit into other culture's mouths. I'll give a quick rundown nonetheless.
If you go out on a sunday, you'll smell asado coming out of every other house you walk across. There are also restaurants specifically just for eating asado and several kinds of meat, but if you manage to make some friends, you might prefer the "authentic" experience and get it done on some dude's backyard. They'll also invariably offer you mate and beer/"fernet con coca".
If you walk around the city, you can sit down just about anywhere and look at the menu. I say milanesa if you're at a restaurant, tostado if you're at a café.
If you're a sweet tooth, walk into a store and get yourself some dulce de leche and alfajores. You'll thank me for the rest of your goddamn life.
If you're into wine, Mendoza is one of the top locations in the world for that stuff. Not much else to add.

>>2332641
>how's the crime in the smaller cities and towns?
There used to be places here where there wasn't much to fear years ago, but the country is going downhill hard, so those places are starting to feel it.
That said, it will be less common than in the big cities. I won't say anywhere near zero, but it's harder to get away with shit when the place is small and everybody knows each other, lel. Town life is mostly chill, but far poorer depending on where you go (the north especially).
>Let's say a town of about 10k -- is there cartel bullshit going on there, or in any of the countryside?
Doubt it, most of the drug trafficking happens around/in the outskirts of the bigger cities (the exception being Rosario, where the WHOLE city is the argentinian equivalent of a mexican narco state, stay the fuck away).
>Do you feel safer in general in the smaller towns than you do in the cities?
Crime can always happen. You will be more "exposed" in small towns and you might be in trouble if you're hurt badly or feel unsafe at a particular moment in time, because small town hospitals have few resources and not as many policemen, while you'll be more prone to it in the cities but at least there are more resources/people to help you. "Safety" kinda depends on how much you can fend for yourself.
>How are the real estate prices there compared to La Tierra de las Hamburguesas?
Don't know much about that, actually, but I can tell you two things:
-Buenos Aires has been having problems reminiscent to that of London this year. Shit is too expensive and too small, so nobody wants it.
-As for the whole country in general, prices are just going up like everything else, so if you're planning to buy something, make sure you bring in as much foreign currency as you can so you don't have to start collecting Monopoly money that will have both lost its value and fallen short of the new price by the time you have it.

>>2327930
Tons of options, red meat in general is awesome but there's also exceptionally good pizzas and ice cream. You can eat a 4-star meal for less than 10 usd.
As for more traditional foods, you can try locro, empanadas, guiso, and if you like sweet stuff, anything with dulce de leche. Like alfajores or facturas that you can buy in panaderias. Croissants with dulce de leche are a must.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2327930
And about the drinking there's pretty good regional beer, and the last decade breweries have opened everywhere in most cities. IPA, APA, scottish, pale, etc.
I don't personally drink wine, but Argentinian wine is highly regarded as one of the best in the world. I've seen tourists praise even the cheap ones.
Decent whisky, outside of your typical brands
Not much vodka, tequila or rum, even though there is enough variety
And then there is Fernet. Mixed with Coke. Oh boy, it has a strong taste so it's a hit or miss, but if it hits, it's heaven.

If you're wondering about non-añcoholic drinks, meh. I guess we have mate, which is an infusion, sorta like herb tea, served on a wooden bowl (also called mate). It's more of a social thing, people sit together and pass the mate around, while chilling, or eating some snacks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2385358
Obviously you will not be fluent in 3 months (that is a task for a lifetime) but with 3 months of serious, consistent effort, you can learn the 2000 or so words you need to express basically any non-abstract thought or request.

It won't feel like much beforehand, but I did this exact thing (learn the 2000 most common words and practice listening/speaking every day for an hour for 3 months) before going to Russia, and the way people treat you with even that level of the language is remarkably different than if you are totally helpless. Most importantly, it turns basic things like ordering food or asking directions into an opportunity for an interesting interaction, rather than a tooth-pulling simulation.

And I know this sort of advice does not actually work on a person who becomes anxious:, but regardless: do remember that most tourists have no knowledge of the country's language whatsoever, so literally anything you can say or do in the language puts you far ahead of the average. From your perspective it might seem embarrassing to struggle with the language, but whatever monolingual person you're talking to is probably quite happy you're attempting to accommodate them, and feels no "vicarious embarrassment" for you.

Also, with that base, you can just barely start to have full conversations with people if you have a knack for languages and, believe me, the same country is two entirely different places when you can speak the language (even a little) vs. when you cant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Do not, under any circumstance, come here if you don't have a remote job that can deposit your wages in a foreign bank.

I translate vidya for foreign clients and teach English at a very nice private school. The translation job, which is a couple hours per day, nets me about 1-1.5k USD per month and lands me somewhere between solid middle class and upper middle class (and I scratch the "rich" tier from time to time). The teaching job nets me about 235 USD per month for two full 7-8 hour days. If I did that all week I'd be lucky to scratch 600 USD per month, working way more hours. And that's a comparatively good salary, there are doctors whose monthly full time income barely beats that, and those guys had to actually make an effort for their degrees and shit.

Yes, living is orders of magnitude cheaper here than in many other countries, but relying on local income paid in our monopoly money currency means you will be subject to the comings and goings of our perpetual misery rollercoaster economy, ever oscillating between "shit is fucked" and "things stabilized a bit but the cocksuckers in charge are refusing to tighten the gibsmedats enough to straighten our ledgers so we're heading for another shitcreek soon" every couple of years. I'm 35 and I've already seen this tango play out several times. It never ends.

tl;dr It's a lovely place in many ways but you need to have a foreign economic tether if you don't want to live under perpetual stress.

I think it's horrible. It's nice if you rent a country house/beach house and stay there drinking, talking, playing games. Camping and other /out/ related trips also might work. But going together to a city demands that people are really considerate of each other (improbable in such a large group). The best is if all of you are capable of splitting so you can easily go each to where you want to meeting again for some meals and one or other activity.
I prefer to travel alone when I go to cities. I had a bad experience with a girlfriend, a good experience with another girl (but few days and we were kind of in a honeymoon) and also mostly bad experiences with friends. With only one friend, it could be great or very hard to get enjoyment. With 2+ friends it was always a hassle. The best places to be with friends imo are those with nothing to do so most of your enjoyment comes from being together talking, saying stupid jokes, and sharing stories and life perspectives.

In a group of 6 there are probably two groups of 3 that are closer, or 3 pairs etc. Identify this, have an honest discussion about it and leave options like "hey we're going to head to this place for 3 nights, we'll meet back up in the city next week" on the table. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The larger the group, the more it will end badly.

Last time we did that, we were four. One has entirely lost contact with the three of us for being an autistic retard (only wanted to eat fastfood, looked at his mobile phone all the time when we were hanging out outside, never takes shower so it started to become smelly etc), and the remaining two, while they are still great friends with me, have stopped talking to each other after the trip for whatever reason.
Living with friends full time in a different country can be extremely different; nobody has the same habit, nor budget and taste. It’s alright on the first few days but after a while, it’s hard. And the biggest issue will always come up at some point: money.
I honestly now only travel on my own, with wife or with my mother as she is very quiet and easy going, eats everything, can skip lunch/dinner when we have to without nagging and so on. It clearly gives you more freedom when you have less people to manage.

It's best if you keep a general idea of what you want to visit but do not keep a strict itinerary. You'll end up splitting in pairs/trios. It could be done as a group with an strict itinerary but it would usually end up in unnecessary fights. Like two guys want to go to a nightclub and end up getting up late. Just get in touch with them and talk about the possibility to split during the trip so no one gets mad when it happens. It will end up happening in a natural way after two or three days. Too many people to keep in line without acting as a bossy guide, something you would not like to do.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2398801
If you think the Splash thing is about forced propaganda you're only partially right. It's being done as an example to the shareholders that the company is moving away from expensive maintenance and operating costs in favor of streamlined low cost and bare minimum crowd appeasement.
You see, a technocratic corporation such as Apple for example, would have little interest in continuing to invest large portions of the company's investments in the parks. So all the animatronics and original themed attractions will continue to be phased out in favor of reducing operating costs and making the Disney brand more valuable to the big buyer, which will definitely be a streaming giant since Disney+ is the company's main focus.
Obviously this also means that virtually nothing from the original Splash will remain. Imagine Frozen Ever After but longer since the layout is the only thing being recycled and that is exactly the attraction youre going to get. There will be a handful of actual animatronics but nothing like the previous amount. And they will mostly be projection mapped and screens will replace the physical sets.
Disney is essentially throwing the towel in to Universal as far as maintaining an equal or competitive quality for the attractions. Their assumption is that they can cut the costs of the parks to appease investors and still maintain the park attendance and money flow that comes from them.
And they are probably right. Look at your average Disney shill, even the casual ones. They will say everything was a worthy replacement regardless and continue to blow their savings each year taking their family because the brand is already engrained into their feeble brains and they will always be loyal no matter what.
In the eyes of the park enthusiasts Universal is about to become leaps and bounds ahead of Disney but that will never translate to fiscal consequence because the vast majority of money generated from Disney parks has nothing to do with these opinions.

Outside observation: It was always a racist country. It was simply slightly less racist than its southern neighbor, the United States.

Canada’s historical mistreatment of its First Nations citizens is on display for the world to see. While the nation had reached some accommodations with the various tribes, it’s still very clear that the First Nations people are viewed as being second class citizens in many areas of Canada, particularly in areas with large populations of tribal members. The poor state of infrastructure on many of the reserves also clearly indicate that the government’s priority is not the residents of those areas.

As far as Blacks: While Canada was never as racist as the Deep South of the United States, segregation (de jure and de facto) were very common in Canada until the 1960s. Black Canadians who descended from either people brought over as slaves, former sea farers and escaped American slaves, lived in segregated areas, faced discrimination for jobs and financing and were often harassed by law enforcement and White Canadians. While this changed drastically in the last 50 years ( due in part to changes in the US and an influx of Afro-Carribbeans and African immigrants and refugees) , racism is not uncommon in areas of Canada which have small non-White populations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393549
Asians - Both East and South Asians have experienced a great deal of discrimination in Canada, although the fact that many came to Canada with wealth or were able to move into the middle and upper classes within a generation or so seems to have tempered this somewhat. Just as in the United States, most Asians and their descendants live in and around the major cities and urban areas, so the prejudice that they experience isn’t as widespread as the prejudice against Blacks and First Nations people seems to be. It does , however exists as referenced below.

Latinos - The recent influx of Latinos into the country seems to have provoked some prejudice against. However, Canada’s Latino population is relatively small, most confined to the cities, and it really hasn’t integrated into the mainstream. As climate change worsens and it becomes clear that Canada can support many more people than its harsh winters currently allows, there are likely to be more immigrations from Latino majority nations which are likely to face the need to flee that change. If history is any indicator if/when their numbers increase, so will the prejudice and discrimination that they face.

Canada is not a bad country, and its racism isn’t as profound as it is in many areas of the United States. It’s not “turning racist.” It IS racist, but it is also slightly less so than many other countries in the Western world.

>>2398333
I was there last month, may have been one of the people on the other thread you mentioned. Definitely would recommend Baalbek and Jeita Grotto. Heard good things about Byblos while there too, but didn't make it there. Like you said everything is close so you can probably do day trips for everything.

For money make sure to bring all the money you will need for the trip into the country in USD and then exchange for the local currency once you arrive.

It isn't so bad as others said here, at least for tourists in my opinion, but I also didn't see the country as it was 10 years ago, which was almost certainly better. You can go and have a good time for sure. One advantage of the current situation is there isn't as many tourists so if you go somewhere like Baalbek for example it won't be full of people.

You can get around pretty inexpensively with their bus system. Can look up how to navigate it if you need. Uber is good, at least around Beirut, but make sure to change your option to Cash on it, else your trip will be hundred of dollars due to exchange.

I felt pretty safe everywhere I went, worst thing that happened was maybe getting charged higher than locals sometimes but it was never ridiculous.

Where I’m moving to isn’t a developing nation, it literally has a higher HDI than my region in England, and frankly most regions here in the UK based on the research I’ve done.

On all fronts, it’s very marginally more expensive than my city in the UK, with average wages basically on-par. I can tell you though, 100% positive, as someone who’s used the public services in both countries from the police to public transport to hospitals, the UK is really, really in a bad state and is incredibly piss poor in those aspects despite the fact that we’re apparently ‘more developed’.

The benefit? I get better weather, prettier surroundings, nicer people and a safer more enjoyable living environment.

Is it perfect? Nah, it has it’s problems, just as you suggested. I’m not deluding myself into some fairytale. For me, the benefit of just being able to wake up in the morning, having a coffee on my balcony at my GFs, whilst overlooking the winding old Mediterranean city streets with the sun shining on my face, outweighs anything I’ll find in the UK.

Don’t get me wrong, I can see why plenty of people in the Mediterranean (for example) want to move to somewhere like the UK. It’s got it’s benefits, for unskilled work there’s better pay, and for more niche career fields/opportunities for progression that wouldn’t necessarily exist at home in abundance, even if the quality of life here isn’t anywhere near as good. Most of those people don’t end up settling here though. They’ll come, earn their money, get their experience or education, then head home after a few years once they’re jaded by it all.

I will also be solo travelling in Rome mid Feb.

Just book a hostel, although I booked mine about a month ago and it was nearly already fully booked then. So you might have some trouble getting somewhere at short notice.
Who you get in your room is pot luck, but its pretty much certain there will be at least some other solo travellers.
My last solo trip everyone in the room was solo, which I think was by design, but I'm not sure how many other hostels do that.

If you're friendly and confident and are not an ugly socially awkward freak then people will be more than willing to chat to you and probably go out for a meal and or drinks.
Just say hi to whoever's in the room when you walk in. Group travellers in your room may well also let you join up with them, its just a bit less common because sometimes they want to get on with their own thing.
Privacy wise try and get a hostel that has a curtain that goes across your bed, if you can't then it shouldnt be too much of a problem anyway, especially only for a few days.

Worth noting that its Valentines day on the 14th, I was slightly worried that the rooms would just be a bunch of couples, but I expect not because that's hardly very romantic.
On the positive side the single girls might be a lot more up for being romanced.

posts.com: Like >>2394178 says OP, it takes time. The most liberating bit of advice I've ever heard is that its impossible to master anything while looking cool, and that particularly goes for social interactions. I plan to start and end with a few days in Dublin, while renting a car and seeing as much of the country as possible in the middle portion. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2397142
Book of Kells is simple but enjoyable.

National Art Gallery and Chester Beaty in Dublin are both worth your time in terms of culture. The latter is small however with 2-3 floors of stuff where you could have a solid time in the former.

Temple Bar with friends is fun albeit expensive.

We also have a wax museum in dublin which is, again small but fun.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
At the Cliffs of Moher, there is the main carpark where you have to pay €12 for admission but there's a smaller carpark nearby. If approaching from the south, it's a left turn before you reach the visitor centre and will be indicated by a sign that says "Guerin's Path to Cliff Walk". If approaching from the North for some reason, it will be on the right after you pass the visitor centre. I think they charge €3 to park there. You can then walk to the visitor centre along the cliff path. You're supposed to have a ticket to get into the centre but if there's no employee standing at the main entrance then you definitely won't be asked for a ticket and you can walk straight in. There's an exhibition with information about the cliffs inside, as well as a gift shop, café and restaurant. O'Brien's tower is the highest point on the cliffs so I would recommend going there for sure to get cool views.
>t. used to work there

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: While you're in Dublin, I recommend taking the train up to Howth (or just driving there I suppose). It was the surprise hit of my trip there last year. You can take a boat out to Ireland's Eye (be sure to get out and walk around rather than just staying on the boat), grab some food around the town port, walk the cliff walk, then see Howth Castle and a dolmen nestled in a rhododendron garden.

posts.name: Anonymous

The National Museum of Ireland was pretty cool. Lots of Stone Age antiques and some preserved bodies pulled from bogs. I did some whiskey tour where they gave us all 5 very generous shots at the end and that got me feeling great for the morning.

If you end up going to Galway and have the time for a day trip, I'd recommend taking the ferry to Inishmore. You can get there in the morning, bike the whole island and leave in the late afternoon. There's a lot of ruins scattered around the island that you can walk around in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2398505
It took me about two months in Hungary. Unlike the US, where you're not supposed to enter on a visa waiver and then switch to a J1 or H1B or similar, European countries generally don't care if you enter on a tourist visa and then apply for a work visa. Since it's much easier to find and apply for work from the country itself, you might consider visiting your destination country, finding a job, and then applying from there (if your budget and current situation allows it).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386906
Rural Colombia is indeed gorgeous in many spots, and Costa Rica has some of the most beautiful concentrated nature I’ve ever seen anywhere, while being safer and easier to get around (although Colombia is mostly safer than its reputation nowadays too). Urban Colombia, however, despite a bit of grit and risk in some spots, is far more charming than urban Costa Rica—San Jose, through which you will have to pass, is an ugly shithole, and while nearly every other town in the country is somewhat more attractive they’re small and have limited historical or cultural interest, apart from Cartago, which has an OK little colonial center.

All that said, the food isn’t particularly good in either country IMO. There are a few local specialties that are worth eating once or twice, but I would say that both Colombian and Costa Rican cooking tend toward the heavy, greasy, and bland.

Mexico or especially Thailand are both far better places to eat as far as I’m concerned. I don’t know Puerto Vallarta specifically, but Mexican beaches I have visited in the Yucatán and Riviera Maya can be very nice if a bit resort/package tourism dominated.

I know Thailand very well—lived there for years—and will always love the place, but I encourage most people to go somewhere other than Bangkok first and see BKK on the way out. I love the place in a lot of ways but love almost everywhere else in the country more. It’s hot, smoggy, has miserable traffic, and isn’t especially attractive, so it can make a bad first impression, but it undeniably has a great deal going on. There are as many favorite beaches there as there are people, but I’ve had great times on Ko Samui (easy mode, avoid Chaweng Beach, which is sleazy and grubby); Phuket (even easier mode, avoid Patong Beach, which is sleazy and grubby and Russian Mafia, I like the southern tip of the island); Ko Chang (no airport so takes a bit longer to reach, mix of hippies and smaller resorts); and others.

>>2389185
The best way is to just not do it. Tell your GP before you go on the trip that you're going on a trip, and you need your prescription for the entire duration of the trip. Add one month or something (depends on the lenght of your trip) to make sure that even if you get delayed for whatever reason you're not left without your presciption.
There are ofc variables, like the majority of the world has cheaper meds than the USA. And also some meds are extremely illegal in some countries, so look it all up. Based on the main ingredient, not the brand name.
In some third world countries your solution might work great, and you might get what you need, for cheaper, too. But let's say you go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to. The only reason to bring your home prescription is in case customs wants to check why you have certain meds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389484
I actually agree with all of your advice here, but
> go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to.

Isn’t necessarily true in my experience. A lot of European cities have walk-in travel clinics for foreigners that can sometimes fill prescriptions for visitors based on a foreign script, with relatively few questions asked. My wife accidentally ran out of thyroid meds while on holiday in Portugal once and was able to get what she needed from a clinic just by showing them the empty box with her name on the prescription label. And when I moved countries, I was able to get an armload of prescriptions from my new GP just by telling him the medications I needed (I have multiple chronic health conditions). That last case is different, of course, because it was implicit that I would have some kind of ongoing relationship with the doctor and he would eventually see blood work for me.

But assuming the medications involved aren’t dangerous or tightly controlled (probably wouldn’t work for anything psychoactive, definitely wouldn’t work for narcotics), it is often possible to get an emergency script from a foreign doctor in the west.

Still agree that the best option is to get a “vacation fill” of whatever you’re on to last as long as you will be away whenever possible, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I hate flying, going to be flying in a month from california to london, what's a drug that's guaranteed to knock me out cold the whole time? I'm awake at night a month ahead thinking about this flight, it's driving me crazy with anxiety. I want to try a few different medications before i go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391230
Ambien or another high-test hypnotic sleeping pill might do the trick. If you’re not concerned about potential abuse and addiction, you might also talk to a doctor about a small quantity of an anxiolytic like Xanax or Ativan, but any drug in the barbiturate or benzodiazepine families is more serious business than people like to think, and shouldn’t be used too casually. They’re all physically habit-forming with nasty withdrawal symptoms, and some people get unpleasant benzo hangovers that can leave you groggy and stupid for an extended period. They can, however, ameliorate anxiety symptoms very effectively in the short term, even if they don’t necessarily render you unconscious.

You should also think about jet lag—I agree with those experts who say that you should avoid trying to sleep at times when you wouldn’t be asleep at your destination while in transit. But it’s virtually impossible to do this perfectly, so if you need to conk out to survive a flight it’s not the end of the world even if it’s suboptimal.

If they haven’t already by the time I finish typing this, someone will surely suggest combining alcohol with one or more of the above. It might work, but I think it’s à fundamentally dumb idea—while alcohol can be good for making you pass out, it’s terrible for sleep quality, so it will make you less likely to stay asleep, and you’re likely to wake up unrested with a hangover in the middle of your flight.

I recommend looking up some anti-anxiety breathing exercises and guided meditation—it may sound like bullshit but in my experience as an anxious person it can also actually work.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
I appreciate the help, i want some hardcore shit, i have all these thoughts of dying already and its a month till my flight, idk i never take any medication or pills of any kind, but im close to cancelling my flight out of fear and i need the assurance i can get something that will make me knock out for 10 hours. I appreciate the advice, i need to go see a doctor ASAP

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
Oh, and if you do end up going with a sleeping pill like Ambien or Lunesta, try it at home a few days before you fly to see how long it lasts in your case, so you can time your dosing appropriately. You will not enjoy dragging your ass through customs and immigration while still deeply under the influence of one of these drugs, nor do you want to still be comatose when you land.

Another psychoactive medication you might want to discuss with your doctor is trazodone; it’s an ancient antidepressant, but it also has some anti-anxiety and sedative properties and used to get prescribed for insomnia. I use a small dose daily at bedtime as part of a depression and anxiety regimen, and while I can’t say it knocks me out for ten hours, it does make me sleepy and I wake up more relaxed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391732
>Any tips on motion sickness pills? Never had them
Many of the OTC ones are based on dimenhydrinate; seems to work OK for my kids. Can make you a bit sleepy but not enough to be used as a sedative. It’s a dissociative/quasi-hallucinogen in the case of massive overdose or deliberate abuse by bored teenagers. Don’t drink alcohol while taking it, less for side effects and more because it seems to stop it from working almost completely.

You can also get scopolamine pills or patches, although these may be script-only depending on where you live; my uncle, who liked deep sea fishing but could also barf walking through a puddle, depended on these.

Another Rx-only drug that in my limited experience might be the most powerful is Ondansetron, AKA Zofran, which can even keep chemotherapy patients from upchucking. My wife got it once in the ER when she had debilitating nausea and she stopped throwing up in seconds, although she had it as an injection rather than a tablet. Not sure if it’s given often for self-administration.

Copper-alloy wristbands and similar talismans work only if you are highly responsive to placebo effects.

Virgin Atlantic has fucked up pricing mostly because it had more difficulty with covid as it is a smaller airline. It declared bankruptcy because of covid (not a going out of business bankruptcy, a restructure/refinance bankruptcy) and is still not doing well. Delta almost owns half the company, operates a bunch of its flights, and Virgin Atlantic is joining Delta's alliance. Prices will probably settle down to standard variability this or next year, but smaller airlines all have more (as a percentage, not total number) weird situations such as you described than larger airlines.

I am my own boss so I can go out any time.

When you’re abroad, at least for me, you become like a toddler. Everything is brand new and you need to learn quick to adapt, whether it’s a few words in a new languages or new cultural norms to get used to. And finally, learn about a lot of things, such as local history, geographical data, wildlife (I do birdwatching and there are species of birds you can never see in other places). Why just look at pictures in the book I have read instead of actually going there?
Learning is life’s greatest pleasure.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2399138
I get a lift from being in new and unfamiliar environments. I also like landscapes/cityscapes, museums, concerts, and historical sites, but even just sitting at a coffeeshop in a place I don’t know is inherently exciting to me. I also get a weird kick out of buying completely mundane things like toothpaste and deodorant. Banal everyday life places and things that are recognizable but not the same are genuinely entertaining for me.

I also like listening to local languages and trying to pick some up, and I like to try unfamiliar food, although I’m not a “foodie” or glutton.

My brother, on the other hand, finds travel inherently uncomfortable, and would generally rather stay home. He will travel to visit me and my family, or to see friends once in a while, and he has fun, but it’s not something he would choose for fun if someone else weren’t making him do it. Different strokes.

Where was the best place you travelled to that had the best fruit - quality, availability, presence of wild fruit, etc?
Obviously the tropics are gonna come out on top here but I'm hoping anons can narrow it down to some region or place that struck them as a cut above the rest. Whether it was wild fruit from foraging or markets in a city with outstanding produce, I'd like to hear your stories.

I haven't been outside Europe so the one place that stood out to me was Uppsala in Sweden - Mulberry, Plum & Cherry trees growing everywhere. In late July & August you can literally eat for free

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Undoubtedly Morocco. As poor as the people are there, I don’t think they realize they have better access to fresh, seasonable produce than most westerners. Last time I was there you could get half a kilo of tangerines for 20¢ and they were always peak ripeness, not hit-and-miss like supermarket citrus. Pomegranates, cherries, all for almost free. A street food specialty in the north are these weird berries called chachnou I’ve never seen anywhere else. In the south it’s prickly pears, which they’ll peel for you so you don’t suffer. The fact that you find all this stuff by wandering through medieval souks is icing on the cake.
For wild foraging, Oahu was good. Lychees fucking everywhere and I found a few weird tropical things including mountain apples and something native to the Philippines which tasted like a strawberry smoothie.
Maine is a paradise for wild blueberries. There’s probably no fruit that even comes close in flavor IMO. You’re allowed to pick them in Acadia NP though unfortunately they ripen at peak tourist season.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: Did I post this in your last thread? Go to France in early November.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: The single best mangoes I have ever tasted, by an order of magnitude, were a variety indigenous to and grown almost exclusively in Haiti. There’s a Dominican cousin that gets exported but it’s inferior. Costa Rica had and Hawaii tied for the finest papaya I’ve ever had—a smaller, lighter-fleshed, less mealy variety than the standard squashlike mush. Thailand is an all-round champ for tropical fruits apart from the aforementioned, but it’s not a great place for wild fruit foraging. In-season cherries from the Pacific Northwest or British Columbia are hard to beat.

Not sure if same as OP, but am from Vancouver and let me give you a breakdown - this is coming from someone born here and mid 20's, social life style

You'll enjoy Vancouver if you're into being a foodie, going into nature for hiking - just google top hikes around north Vancouver if you don't want to travel 1+ hour away,

Try the Japanese food, known for it and it lives up to it,

Clubbing scene is decent if youre into the night life, it's bland compared to US but it's fine. Greta is a new popular spot.

Nature stuff are day trips for the most part, could do hike in the morning, and end it off in the city.

For pot there's Cannabis Culture Lounge where you can chill and buy a blunt there, pretty nice spot and in downtown vancouver

Museums suck, Art Galleries here suck

Spend more time in Nature than the City here, trust me on that

Oh and lots of cool coffee shops and cafe vibes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>City life, besides using Google, any other spots in the city I we should go to?
IDK how long you are planning on staying but the city itself is somewhat lacking from a tourist perspective. It's a great place to live. But there is no real reason to spend more than say 3 days downtown. If you have the time Whistler and Victoria are worth going to. If you're going in the summer something like Penticton (or at least Kelowna/Kamloops.)might be worth going as well.

Personally I'd make the trip a three stop leg of Vancouver - Seattle - Portland
or Vancouver- Victoria - Seattle.
But I'm also not the biggest nature guy so if your for that: Deep cove is the 10 minute IG girl hike. Garibaldi Lake is the actually much prettier hike with more to see and camping spots. (not glamping though)
People also like Tofino but I have no idea why, and it is a pain in the ass to get to.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The two cities couldn’t be much more different. Have you ever been to either?

Bangkok is somewhat cheaper, somewhat dirtier, quite a lot hotter, much smoggier (although I’ve been told that there are seasonal air quality problems in TPE too, it was fairly clear on my two visits), and close to five times the size of Taipei. Taipei is a fairly large place, but Bangkok’s much closer to a megacity, and it feels like one. If you’re used to small towns or easily overwhelmed, BKK is probably going to be harder to deal with than Taipei, which is in large part relatively orderly where Bangkok can be chaotic.

Personally, I would rather live in Thailand (I was there for several years, including a year in Bangkok), but I think Taipei is an easier place by a lot of metrics. I prefer the food, and I enjoy a bit of chaos.

English proficiency isn’t particularly good in Thailand outside of relatively narrow tourist areas, and most Thai women are disinclined to date foreigners, in part because they don’t want to be mistaken for prostitutes, who are treated like absolute shit by locals. There are exceptions, including very rich girls, party girls, and girls with their hands out, but no matter what sexpats/sex tourists manage to convince themselves, being a white guy does NOT make you more attractive or interesting in Thailand in general.

Not 100% sure how much better the English is among average Taiwanese, as I’ve always been visiting an expat friend and his Taiwanese wife when I’ve been there, so I both met people who spoke English fairly well and had a handy translator, but my surface impressions are that the average proficiency levels among young people are at least a little higher. And although my sample size is small I had a clear impression that dating white folks isn’t as stigmatized there.

No idea about Taiwanese residency policies, but know that despite its popularity among laptop hobos, Thailand is explicitly not a digital nomad-friendly country.

You got many things wrong in that sentence.
1) You don't need a WHV to work as a digital nomad, you can just renew your visa exemption by leaving the territory every three month (aka visa run)
2) "leaving the territory" =/= "going back home". If you do a visa run or get a WH visa, if you do indeed need to leave the territory (not sure of that in some cases), just book a flight to the philippines for 200 bucks a roundtrip, and an airbnb for dirt cheap for a couple of days or just one, enjoy, and come back. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381428
It really all depends on your tastes, anon. But if you want the most bang for your buck, plan a trip to do two of these cities at the same time. For example, the ferry from HK to Macau is only 40 bucks (roundtrip) and Shenzhen is right at the border. So you could like, leave a day or two for visiting Macau and do the rest of the week in Hong Kong visiting the city, museums, the nearby greenery or simply just having fun. Same goes for Singapore and Kuala lumpur, a simple bus trip of a few hours gets you from one to the other.

Same goes for Japan. Kyoto and Osaka (+kobe) are basically the same city. only issue is if you want to do Tokyo too, in which case an overnight bus trip (500km) won't cost much. And Same goes for Seoul/Busan (300km)
Taking this into account, you can easily see that HK/Shenzhen/Macau is a great deal and so is Kyoto/Osaka/Kobe (kobe is definitely worth a visit !), especially if you can fit Tokyo into your timetable/budget. I'd also put Malacca/Kuala Lumpur/Singapore as another trio worth visiting.

On the other hand, there are places where it's worth just taking 2-4 weeks, find an appartment or airbnb to rent, and pretend you've lived there all your life. These places are Chongqing and Taipei, in my opinion. They're relatively peaceful places with not much shit to do but basically go on a walking adventure around the city, discover the people, hear their stories. Maybe have a love story. Maybe look at the job situation so you can make it there. Who knows.

>Beijing
Huge roads, not walkable, shit public transport, gray, businesses mostly in big ass malls, shit nightlife (as in, night street food, night restaurants etc). Very restrictive so not many small things going on.

>>2381428
Here's the Cyberpunk rankings of the cities I've visited so far:

Tokyo (7/10) (overated- too clean and tidy)
Seoul (7/10) (overated- has too much of a boring American "grid" like layout)
Busan (8/10) (underated- multiple skyscraper urban cores tucked in between mountains and hills filled with favela looking "slums", good mix of grit and modern/sleek)
Kyoto (0/10) (Asking if Kyoto is Cyberpunk is like asking if Florence, Italy is Cyberpunk. No.)
Jakarta (6/10) (too "low life" and not enough "high tech", its just a giant open sewer slum with some high end shopping malls in the center)

Some others
Bangkok (9/10) (100% Blade Runner/Night City, my favorite on this list, only reason its not a 10 is because I havent been to China yet which I imagine would take all perfect 10/10 rankings)
Saigon (8/10) (the "low life" aspect among neon grit is well represented, but a little lacking in the balance of modern infrastructure, skyscrapers and urban verticality outside of a very small area of District 1- give it time though, the city is building up fast and will probably take a 10/10 spot some day)

Keep in mind, this was all before COVID though- 2018 and 2019- and I imagine lockdowns killed any sort of that Cyberpunk "wild west", hustle and bustle feeling these places used to have. I imagine theyre all a lot quieter now and all the small businesses are mostly shuttered.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Some of the cities mentioned in this thread are too 'clean' to be cyberpunk. More like cyberpop. Look for cities that have large slums; the more populated the slums, the more likely it is to become cyberpunk, as the slums begin to stack on top one another. Bonus points if it's next to high rise skyscrapers in a densely packed area. Also, look at rapidly developing countries which are industrial & thus are very polluted. The destruction of the environment is a major trope in cyberpunk; places with lots of smog, terrible weather, rivers of trash, e-waste will definitely fit this.

Other tropes are the feeling of isolation in a densely packed area, orwellian surveillance and the 'sin city' factor, especially if it's open-air/ungoverned/state sanctioned.
Think the 7 sins:

Lust: escorts, massage parlors, love hotels, easy access p0rn, hypersexuality, gay bath houses, ladyboys
Gluttony: fast food, binge drinking, gold plated food, silver facials, excessive materialism/consooming
Greed: crypto, casinos/gambling, stock market, hustlers, gig economy, cash4gold, various scams, black market (silk road, organ harvesting),
Sloth: high automation, widespread apathy/nihilism, indifference to cruelty/bystander effect (watching people die, ignoring untouchables), promoting laziness
Wrath: war propaganda, political/ethnic/religious scapegoats blasted on media, eye 4 an eye mentality, cheering on violent/self-destructive behavior, sanctioned gangrapes, crimewave, gangs, police brutality, rudeness
Envy: sports cars, bling, expensive bags, photoshopped models, paradise packages, high rise condos next to slums, celebrities
Pride: social media, taking pride in degeneracy, ethno-narcissism, hyper-nationalism, religious zealots, promoting vanity

Which cities come to mind? Next time you re in a big city, look around for the 7 sins and tropes such as class disparity, pollution, industrialization, automation, overpopulation etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395382
Been there last year, I will summarize:

Tolls EVERYWHERE, factor that into travel costs, probably paying about 10 euro every 100 km.
Look for quieter spots that dont have tons of "foreign" tourists, my personal favourite was Kamena Vourla - it was mostly greeks on domestic holidays. Second favourite was Mytikas because it was much quieter than others.
Many of the roads and streets are poor and the drivers are crazy so always keep it in the back of your head to be careful.
Snacks are expensive, you want a bottle of coke? Some places sell 500ml cokes for 3 euro.
There are quite varying temperatures across the country, next to the ocean is generally cooler but in the midlands it can be agonizingly hot.
If driving, make sure to visit petrol stations often, lots of them close on a Sunday too so don't get stuck!
The Greeks are very kind (when they are not driving) and will talk to you if they can, some even took us home and were very hospitable.
Pay attention to google maps - if you are sure you have the right place but the journey says it takes a crazy long time, there is likely a valid reason (landslides etc).
A lot of places do not let you put normal toilet roll in the toilet - I wish I was kidding but they expect you to shit, wipe, and put your shitty wipes in the bin next to the toilet. This was honestly the most disgusting thing about Greece, I didn't even see one bidet.
