I work for a major, international corporate entity.

I work from home, however, I use extremely specific software and rely on a data interface which is tightly relegated to my work laptop which they have provided me with.

To log on to my work laptop, I have to log in through a company VPN, which of course exposes my location.

My company is extremely anal about security. I have a cunt of a line manager, which makes it near impossible for me to raise the question of working abroad with her. I know she’ll get uppity and cause problems; the main reason being that if I have technical issues with my laptop, which happens often due to the precarious nature of our software, I’m required to go to my place of work and get the IT team to take a look.

My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?

The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.

Anyone got any advice?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
I'd say 98% yes - the remote IP address they'll see you connecting from will be an IP address belonging to the foreign telco provider. It won't be one of the IP addresses of your home telco provider.
The 2% chance I'm holding back is because I'm aware some telcos do have the options of SIMs with fixed IP addresses tied to them. Without knowing where you are from and what telco you use, I've gotta put that chance as low.
>The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.
I wouldn't put too much weight on this, but you could tell pretty easily by visiting whatsmyip.com while using your SIM abroad and seeing what it says.

There are ways you can get around having a foreign IP address. Others have probably talked about them already, but they come down to using a router or gateway device that can use a VPN. On that device you'd use a VPN (preferably to a friend's home network in your home country, but maybe ExpressVPN will work for you since many of their exit nodes are partnered with local ISPs). Then you connect your work laptop to that router/gateway device. Your work laptop connects to the company VPN and your company VPN sees it coming from the personal/ExpressVPN address your router/gateway is using. If you do this route, you need a router/gateway that with a killswitch that will completely drop your internet interface if the VPN drops.
I think your big problem is having flaky work software that require you to bring the laptop to the office to fix. Maybe get a second work laptop for your "month at the cottage"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
Yeah, they would. International roaming depends on your carrier's agreement with some local carrier to provide you service in order to work. So when you try to log in, it'll show that country's location.

And it's not a guarantee you'll be able to get 5G wherever you go. Even in Europe. I paid my American carrier for unlimited roaming internet while abroad (again, it was a French carrier providing me the actual service, you can only do this a few months before they cut you off anyway), and I bought a French SIM card, and even then, the best I could get was 4G.

Besides that, if your company really is anal about security then there's no way in hell you'll be able to hide the fact that you're abroad from them. The fact that you would even ask this means you aren't technically sophisticated enough to outwit your IT department. You'd only end up getting yourself in trouble.

My advice would be that, if working abroad means that much to you (and I can understand that, because it's a life-changing perk) then I would suggest you look for a job with a company that's willing to look the other way. This means banks and security work are probably a no-go for you (though there are surely exceptions). You should be looking for a new job constantly anyway, so that your compensation is as high as it can be.

Many companies won't allow you to work from abroad, if only to save themselves the tax and legal troubles they would have to figure out in another country. But if you use an American mailing address (say, your parents') and give them plausible deniability, many companies are willing to look the other way to keep valuable employees, including mine.
